examples.en: Let's go with the next bus.
examples.ja: 次のバスで行きましょう。

examples.en: Do you have the day off on the next day?
examples.ja: 次の日は、お休みですか？

examples.en: It's your turn next.
examples.ja: 次は、あなたです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

Someone yells out "NEXT!" because the first thing didn't work on you. That was a single guillotine. Now they are going to try <reading>two gui</reading>llotines (つぎ) and see how that works on your thick neck. NEXXXXT!

examples.en: The car went in a southeast direction.
examples.ja: 車は、南東の方に行った。

examples.en: The office building is facing southeast.
examples.ja: 会社のビルは南東を向いています。

examples.en: The southeast gets good sun light.
examples.ja: 南東は、よく日が当たります。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>South</kanji> <kanji>East</kanji> is the <vocabulary>Southeast</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings for both kanji. You've seen those readings before in 南米 and 東京, for example, so you should be good to go here!

examples.en: My brother is an assistant of a psychologist.
examples.ja: 弟は心理学者の助手です。

examples.en: My assistant is also the mother of three children.
examples.ja: 私の助手は三人の子の母でもあります。

examples.en: As the president's assistant, I do things like getting coffee and answering the phone for them.
examples.ja: 社長の助手として、コーヒーを買ってきたり、電話に出たりします。

examples.en: If I'm the assistant to an assistant who was just fired, does that mean that I’m fired too?
examples.ja: 仮に私が首になった助手の助手だとしたら、それってつまり私も首になっちゃったってこと？

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 手 can mean a "doer" in some words? What do you think your <kanji>help</kanji> <kanji>doer</kanji> is? It’s someone who helps you, so it’s your <vocabulary>assistant</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>helper</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>aide</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned the on'yomi reading of 手 with the vocabulary word 投手.

examples.en: Those sisters are still confronting each other.
examples.ja: あの姉妹はまだ対立している。

examples.en: I want to stop the conflict between my father and my brother.
examples.ja: 父と兄の対立を止めたいです。

examples.en: Please tell me the reason for the conflict.
examples.ja: 対立の理由を教えて下さい。

meaning_mnemonic:
If it's you <kanji>versus</kanji> someone else and you're <kanji>stand</kanji>ing in each other's way, you're in <vocabulary>conflict</vocabulary>. Better hope they're not bigger than you, or this <vocabulary>confrontation</vocabulary> might turn out to be a bad idea…

対立 is when two sides are in conflict, usually because their ideas, goals, or interests just don't match. It's the kind of <vocabulary>opposition</vocabulary> where neither side wants to back down, and they just keep standing against each other.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It takes time to decide which tie to wear every day.
examples.ja: 毎日、ネクタイを決めるのに時間がかかります。

examples.en: I decided to enroll in a private university.
examples.ja: 私立大学に入学することに決めました。

examples.en: Have you decided on the restaurant you'll go to with Koichi tonight?
examples.ja: 今日の夜、コウイチと行くレストランは、もう決めましたか？

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>decide</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to decide</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have <vocabulary>to decide</vocabulary>. You have two <reading>key</reading>s (き) in front of you. You have to decide on one of them and use it to unlock the door to get away from the monster. Why do monster attacks always come down to keys and doors?

examples.en: Last year, I started a new life in Nagoya.
examples.ja: 去年、名古屋での新しい生活を始めました。

examples.en: I've just started WaniKani.
examples.ja: 私は、まだワニカニを始めたばかりです。

examples.en: I want to learn Spanish, but I don't know where to start.
examples.ja: スペイン語を学びたいけど、何から始めるのがいいのか、分かりません。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>begin</kanji> or <kanji>start</kanji>, and the verb version is <vocabulary>to begin</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to begin something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to start</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to start something</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. You start something. Like studying! You should have started studying earlier though, huh?
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

Right now it's time <vocabulary>to begin</vocabulary> <reading>Haj</reading> (はじ). (Haj is the fifth pillar of Islam, and is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja). You need to start Haj right now!

examples.en: My father likes bitter coffee.
examples.ja: 父は苦いコーヒーを気に入ってます。

examples.en: Is there a bitter fruit in this world?
examples.ja: 苦いフルーツなんて、この世の中に有るんですか？

examples.en: Be careful not to let the caramel burn or it will taste bitter.
examples.ja: カラメルは、こがさないように気を付けてください。でないと、苦い味になってしまいます。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji for 苦 means <kanji>suffering</kanji>. This word, however, is a bit different, but you'll see how it's related. It means <vocabulary>bitter tasting</vocabulary>. Think of putting the most <vocabulary>bitter</vocabulary> thing in the world in your mouth. You feel sick, your mouth gets all weird, and you try to spit it out but the bitterness remains. Obviously eating bitter tasting things will cause you to suffer.
reading_mnemonic:
This reading of the kanji is unique to this meaning of the word, so here's a mnemonic to help you out!

The taste is so <vocabulary>bitter tasting</vocabulary> that you fall to your knees really, really hard. Luckily, you were wearing your <reading>knee gua</reading>rds (にが). Feel the relief that you were wearing them. Ack, no relief now. It's still bitter in your mouth.

examples.en: In Japan, is it possible to take a dog with you in a taxi?
examples.ja: 日本では、犬をタクシーに乗せることは出来ますか？

examples.en: I loaded a suitcase into the vehicle.
examples.ja: 今、車内にスーツケースを乗せました。

examples.en: It's rude to put your feet on a table.
examples.ja: テーブルに足を乗せるのは失礼ですよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>ride</kanji> so this word has to do with riding. There's another word that's similar (乗る which means to ride). This particular one is transitive, meaning there is a direct object. The action is done to someone or something. So this means <vocabulary>to give someone a ride</vocabulary> when it's used for people, and <vocabulary>to place something on</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to load something</vocabulary> when it's used for things. 

Use the せ as a hint. The せ is a "sail" (せ) that you use on your boat to give someone a ride. How nice of you.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is kun'yomi (see that hiragana?) but that's the reading you learned with the kanji so you should be okay with this. Allow me to give you a ride to the next item to study.

examples.en: This suitcase is heavy.
examples.ja: このスーツケースは重いですよ。

examples.en: I want to use this big, heavy rock as a bench.
examples.ja: この大きくて重い石を、ベンチの代わりに使いたいと思います。

examples.en: Now that I remember today's exams, I feel reluctant to go to school.
examples.ja: 今日の試験のことを思い出すと、学校への足が重い。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>heavy</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>heavy</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You're lifting something that's really <vocabulary>heavy</vocabulary>. Oof! You lift it above your head. You're so awesome. You scream: "<reading>OH! MO</reading>RE!" (おも) they put more. You yell it again: "OH, MORE!" and again: "OH, MORE!" Go ahead and act this out wherever you are, pretending like you're holding a couch or two or three over your head, saying "OH MORE!"

examples.en: My father gets up at 6:00 every morning.
examples.ja: 父は、毎朝六時に起きる。

examples.en: Did you wake up already? It's still 4:00 a.m.
examples.ja: もう起きたの？まだ午前四時だよ。

examples.en: A miracle may have happened.
examples.ja: ミラクルが起きたかもしれない。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>wake up</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to wake up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to get up</vocabulary>.

This word also has a secondary meaning of <vocabulary>to occur</vocabulary>. Think of it this way: when an action "wakes up", in a way it is occurring as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, so tomorrow when you wake up you hopefully won't have to relearn this vocab's reading.

examples.en: I immediately downloaded a new app.
examples.ja: 早速、新しいアプリをダウンロードしました。

examples.en: Thank you very much for your prompt reply.
examples.ja: 早速のお返事、どうもありがとうございます。

examples.en: Immediately after becoming independent, I bought my own car with my own money.
examples.ja: 自立してから早速、自分の車を自分のお金で買いました。

meaning_mnemonic: Doing something both <kanji>fast</kanji> and <kanji>early</kanji> probably requires you to do it <vocabulary>at once</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>immediately</vocabulary>. Whatever it is, be sure to do it <vocabulary>without delay</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this one is strange. The reading for 速 (そく) is what you'd expect (on'yomi), but 早 gets a reading you haven't seen before, meaning you should treat this as an exception. Just think about how you're learning this word <vocabulary>at once</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>without delay</vocabulary> so there's no time for any <reading>sa</reading>ss (さっ), just kanji learning.

examples.en: These internet speeds are too slow and it’s pissing me off.
examples.ja: インターネットの速度がおそすぎてイライラしています。

examples.en: Lower the speed a little more, please.
examples.ja: もう少し速度を下げて走行してください。

examples.en: My older sister ran to school at such an incredible speed, with bread in her mouth.
examples.ja: 姉は朝ごはんの食パンを口に入れたまま、すごい速度で学校に走っていきました。

meaning_mnemonic:
Your <kanji>fast</kanji>ness <kanji>degree</kanji> is your <vocabulary>speed</vocabulary>. 

You use 速度 to talk about a specific speed of something like a car or a train. If you want to talk about speed more casually, you can just say スピード or 速さ.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The teacher distributes the paper for the exam.
examples.ja: 先生が試験の紙を配る。

examples.en: Female students in Japan pass out handmade chocolates at school on Valentine's Day.
examples.ja: 日本の女子学生たちは、バレンタインデーに学校で手作りのチョコレートを配るんです。

examples.en: Can I do a part-time job to distribute newspapers while running?
examples.ja: 新聞を配るバイトって、ランニングしながらでも出来ますか？

examples.en: This party blows. Even passing out pocket tissues on the street would be better.
examples.ja: このパーティー、本気でつまんない。道でティシュでも配ってる方がマシだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>distribute</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to distribute</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You’re going <vocabulary>to distribute</vocabulary> flyers about your favorite country: <reading>Cuba</reading> (くば). You’re the biggest Cubaboo there has ever been, so you’ll gladly stand out in the street distributing flyers about Cuba all day long… right?

examples.en: Does this drink contain alcohol?
examples.ja: このドリンクはお酒が入ってますか？

examples.en: In Japan, only adults over twenty years old can drink.
examples.ja: 日本で、お酒を飲めるのは二十才以上の大人だけです。

examples.en: I don't have much alcohol tolerance, so I will have tea.
examples.ja: お酒に弱いので、お茶をいただきます。

meaning_mnemonic: This is just the noun version of the kanji 酒 - it has an お there to be nice. This word can mean both <vocabulary>alcohol</vocabulary> (like the parent kanji) or <vocabulary>sake</vocabulary> (the main kind of Japanese alcohol, at least back in the kanji days).
reading_mnemonic: The reading is kun'yomi, which isn't what you learned with the kanji. But, it should be pretty easy. You know what Japanese alcohol is called already, right? It's <reading>さけ</reading>, simple as that. So long as you've heard of sake you should be A-Okay with this reading.

examples.en: My father doesn't drink much sake on weekdays.
examples.ja: 父は平日は日本酒をあまり口にしない。

examples.en: The bartender made a cocktail that is mixed with sake.
examples.ja: バーテンダーが日本酒を交ぜたカクテルを作りました。

examples.en: You should drink a lot of sake while you're in Japan. It is expensive to buy sake in the United States.
examples.ja: 日本にいる間に、たくさんのんでね。アメリカで日本酒を買うと高いですから。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 日本 is "Japan" so when you add <kanji>alcohol</kanji> onto the end of that you have <vocabulary>Japanese Style Alcohol</vocabulary> (what's the big Japanese style alcohol that everyone knows? That's <vocabulary>sake</vocabulary>).
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this is just the vocab 日本's primary reading plus the on'yomi you learned for 酒, put together.

examples.en: It takes about a thousand yen to get to the hospital by taxi.
examples.ja: 病院までタクシーで、千円ぐらいです。

examples.en: My mother is in the hospital, so I go there every day.
examples.ja: お母さんが病院にいるので、毎日病院に通っています。

examples.en: That white building is a municipal hospital.
examples.ja: あの白いビルは、市立病院です。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>sick</kanji> <kanji>institution</kanji> is a place where sick people go. That is a <vocabulary>hospital</vocabulary>.

病院 is a broad word used to talk about not just big hospitals but also regular <vocabulary>doctor's office</vocabulary>s or <vocabulary>clinic</vocabulary>s. So when Japanese people speak English, they might say "hospital" even when they are just going to a small, local clinic.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I am studying psychology at Tofugu Institute.
examples.ja: 私はトーフグ学院で心理学を学んでいます。

examples.en: My friend entered the Bunka Gakuin in 2014.
examples.ja: 友人は、2014年に文化学院に入学しました。

examples.en: The academy mainly teaches science and mathematics.
examples.ja: 学院では主に科学と数学の科目を教えています。

examples.en: Aoyama Gakuin University is the name of a university in Tokyo.
examples.ja: 青山学院大学は東京にある大学の名前です。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>study</kanji> <kanji>institution</kanji> is an <vocabulary>academy</vocabulary>. That's where all the fancy people study, anyways.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I want to go to the ocean before the summer vacation is over.
examples.ja: 夏休みが終わる前に、海に行きたいです。

examples.en: Today's class is all done.
examples.ja: 今日のクラスは全て終わりました。

examples.en: The construction of the road in front of the studio is taking time to be completed, so I can't concentrate on recording podcasts.
examples.ja: スタジオの前の道路の工事が中々終わらないので、ポッドキャストのレコーディングに集中できません。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>end</kanji>, so this verb means <vocabulary>to end</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be over</vocabulary>.

Verbs ending in okurigana that rhyme with ある tend to be intransitive, and 終わる is usually intransitive too. But sometimes it can be transitive and take a direct object. Kind of like "to end" in English — you can say the class ends (intransitive) or a teacher ends their class (transitive).
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

This situation has <vocabulary>to end</vocabulary>. You're the <reading>ower</reading> (おわ) of a lot of money. For this to end, you need to pay back all that money. Try to think of ways to stop being an ower so this stressful situation can end!

examples.en: This train runs until the last stop.
examples.ja: この電車は終点まで走行します。

examples.en: What's the name of the last stop on this Amtrak leaving from Chicago?
examples.ja: このシカゴ発のアムトラックの終点の駅は何ていう名前ですか。

examples.en: The endpoint of this hiking trail is roughly around here on the map.
examples.ja: このハイキングコースの終点は、地図で見ると、大体この辺りです。

examples.en: No matter what I say, no matter what I do, please do not let me get out of the train until it gets to the last stop. Okay?
examples.ja: 私が仮に何と言っても、何をしようとも、終点までは、私が電車から出ないようにして。分かった？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>end</kanji> <kanji>point</kanji> is where everything ends... but for this example, think of a map with a route on it. The last spot on the route is the "last point." It is the <vocabulary>last stop</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The meeting has ended.
examples.ja: ミーティングは終了しました。

examples.en: All of the work is scheduled to be completed by the end of the month.
examples.ja: 全ての作業は月末までに終了する予定です。

examples.en: My favorite drama ended in one season.
examples.ja: 気に入ったドラマが一シーズンで終了してしまった。

meaning_mnemonic:
It's the <kanji>end</kanji>. It's the <kanji>finish</kanji>. This word means <vocabulary>end</vocabulary>. Or <vocabulary>finish</vocabulary>! How convenient.

Note that 終了 is slightly more formal than 終わる.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: When does the last bus leave?
examples.ja: 最終のバスはいつ出発ですか？

examples.en: This episode is the final episode of the series.
examples.ja: このエピソードがシリーズの最終回です。

examples.en: The final decision will be later made by the president.
examples.ja: 最終決定は、後で社長がします。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>most</kanji> <kanji>end</kanji> thing is the <vocabulary>last</vocabulary> thing. It is mainly used to refer to the <vocabulary>last</vocabulary> of an ordered sequence.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This is a classroom to learn Japanese manners.
examples.ja: ここは、日本のマナーを習う教室です。

examples.en: Excuse me, I would like to learn Spanish composition.
examples.ja: すみません、スペイン語の作文を習いたいんですが。

examples.en: Junior high school students in this town are all taking lessons in piano or soccer.
examples.ja: この町の中学生は、みんなピアノかサッカーを習っています。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>learn</kanji> so the vocab verb version means <vocabulary>to learn</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to take lessons in</vocabulary> something.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have <vocabulary>to learn</vocabulary> about <reading>Nara</reading>, the city of deer... lots and lots of deer. If you don't know about it, how about learning about it?

examples.en: There was a sound of a ball rolling.
examples.ja: ボールが転がる音がした。

examples.en: For caterpillars, there are probably many lying down around there.
examples.ja: 毛虫なら、その辺りにたくさん転がってるでしょう。

examples.en: A rolling stone? Do you mean the English rock band The Rolling Stones?
examples.ja: 転がる石？イギリスのロックバンド「ザ・ローリング・ストーンズ」のことですか？

meaning_mnemonic: You know the kanji here means revolve. The verb version of this is similar. It means to roll or to tumble. You have to be revolving in order to roll or tumble, right? 転がる is intransitive, so it doesn't take a direct object. A ball rolls down a hill. A tumbleweed tumbles. No direct object, right? Verbs ending in okurigana that rhyme with ある tend to be intransitive like this. You can remember this because if something is ある, it's just there, existing, not acting on anything else. That's why verbs that sound like it are often intransitive too!
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

What should you do when you want <vocabulary>to roll</vocabulary> down a hill? Become a bottle of <reading>Coro</reading>na (ころ). Just imagine yourself as a bottle of Corona, rolling down a hill. You're a Corona bottle, so you roll super easily. Now feel the grass under your glass as you roll down that hill. Nice, isn't it?

examples.en: Excuse me. Is there bicycle parking around here?
examples.ja: すみません。この辺に自転車のパーキングはありますか？

examples.en: I go to the baking workshop every day by bicycle.
examples.ja: 私は毎日自転車でパン作り教室に通っています。

examples.en: I'll buy you a new bicycle. I don't need anything in return!
examples.ja: 自転車を買ってあげるよ。お返しは要らないからね！

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>self</kanji> <kanji>revolving</kanji> <kanji>car</kanji>. You'd think this would be a regular car, but <vocabulary>bicycles</vocabulary> were probably introduced before cars were, meaning the self revolving car is the bicycle, not the car. Just imagine yourself on a bike, and you don't even have to move the pedals. They revolve themselves, but now you're going too fast and it's scary.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My father drives his car or motorcycle every day between his company and home.
examples.ja: 父は毎日、会社と家の間を車かバイクで運転する。

examples.en: I only drive on my days off.
examples.ja: 私は休日しか運転しません。

examples.en: Do you have a license to steer a ship?
examples.ja: 船を運転するライセンスは持ってますか？

meaning_mnemonic: A thing that <kanji>carries</kanji> <kanji>rotation</kanji>s (think wheels!) is most kinds of vehicles. So, it's kind of like saying you're "doing vehicles" here... but that doesn't make sense. What do you do to vehicles though? You drive them. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to drive</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word with the on'yomi readings you learned, plus する attached at the end to turn it into a verb. As long as you know the readings of your kanji, you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Could you forward that email to me?
examples.ja: そのメール、私にも転送してくれない？

examples.en: Japanese people who reside overseas often buy things from Japanese websites and have them forwarded to the foreign addresses.
examples.ja: 海外に住んでいる日本人は、よく日本のウェブサイトから物を買って、海外の住所に転送しています。

examples.en: Large data above five gigabytes takes time to transfer.
examples.ja: 五ギガバイト以上の大きなデータは、転送するのに時間がかかります。

meaning_mnemonic:
You <kanji>revolve</kanji> something, making it roll, and then <kanji>send</kanji> it off somewhere. This means you’re <vocabulary>transfer</vocabulary>ring or forwarding it to someone else.

転送 is often used in the context of logistics or communication systems, like transferring packages or forwarding e-mails.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The tires revolve when the car runs.
examples.ja: 車は、走る時にタイヤが回転します。

examples.en: This is the sound of a pet hamster spinning their wheel.
examples.ja: これは、ペットのハムスターが回し車を回転させている音です。

examples.en: The other day, I went to a revolving sushi restaurant.
examples.ja: 先日、回転ずし屋に出かけました。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>revolve</kanji> X number of <kanji>times</kanji>. Really, the times isn't so important, but the revolving is. That's why this word is <vocabulary>revolve</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>rotate</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. P.S. Ever heard of "回転ずし?" That's the kind of sushi that's on conveyor belts, rotating around and around, bringing you delicious plates of things.

examples.en: Please move a little more forward.
examples.ja: もう少し前に進んで下さい。

examples.en: Is the project moving forward?
examples.ja: プロジェクトは進んでますか？

examples.en: The car does not go forward for some reason, even though I'm stepping on the gas pedal.
examples.ja: アクセルをふんでるのに、なぜか車が進みません。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>advance</kanji> so the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to advance</vocabulary>.

進む is an intransitive verb, meaning it describes something or someone moving (む) forward. It can be used for physical movement, like a person walking forward or a clock running fast, or for abstract progress, like in someone's work or studies.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

In order <vocabulary>to advance</vocabulary>, you must <reading>sue Sue</reading> (すす) for her misdeeds against you. Imagine her standing in your way, literally. She keeps saying, "You'll have to sue me if you want <vocabulary>to move forward</vocabulary>!" So you do — you sue Sue. That way, you can finally move on with your life.

examples.en: Cosplay culture continues to evolve day by day.
examples.ja: コスプレ文化は日々進化し続けている。

examples.en: Evolved scientific technology supports our lives.
examples.ja: 進化した科学テクノロジーが私たちの生活を支えています。

examples.en: Hey, mom. What will humans become when we evolve?
examples.ja: ねえ、ママ。人間は進化したら何になるの？

meaning_mnemonic: Think of things that <kanji>advance</kanji> and <kanji>change</kanji>. Does this sound familiar? Does this sound like <vocabulary>evolution</vocabulary>?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The construction of the road is progressing.
examples.ja: 道の工事が進行しています。

examples.en: The other day, I reported on the progress status of the project.
examples.ja: 先日、プロジェクトの進行ステータスをリポートしました。

examples.en: The new vaccine made from blowfish extract has suppressed the progression of the disease.
examples.ja: フグのエキスから作られた新しいワクチンが病気の進行を止めました。

meaning_mnemonic:
When something <kanji>advance</kanji>s and <kanji>go</kanji>es, it is moving forward. So this means <vocabulary>advance</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>progress</vocabulary>.

進行 can be used to describe various situations, like when a project progresses; but also when an illness advances to a more serious stage.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Did you hear the snow falling just now?
examples.ja: 今、雪が落ちる音がしませんでした？

examples.en: My brother fell off the tree trying to catch insects.
examples.ja: 弟は虫を取ろうとして、木から落ちてしまいました。

examples.en: A lot of colorful leaves have fallen on the ground.
examples.ja: 土の上にはカラフルな葉がたくさん落ちていました。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>fall</kanji> and the vocab verb version means <vocabulary>to fall down</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to fall</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>to drop</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>to fail</vocabulary>, in the sense of failing an exam.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

If you start <vocabulary>to fall down</vocabulary>, what do you yell? "<reading>OHHHH</reading> (お)!"

examples.en: Last summer, we went to a mountain with beautiful fresh leaves.
examples.ja: 去年の夏、青葉が美しい山へ行きました。

examples.en: Three days ago, I found a small white flower in the greenery
examples.ja: 三日前、青葉の中に小さな白い花があるのを見つけた。

examples.en: It's good for your eyes to see greenery.
examples.ja: 青葉を見るのは目にいい事ですよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>young</kanji> <kanji>leaf</kanji> is exactly what you'd expect, although most people usually just call them <vocabulary>fresh leaves</vocabulary>.

Remember how there's some overlap between blue and green in Japanese? 青葉 is another example!  That's why 青 is used to describe fresh and lush green leaves, especially those on trees during early summer.
reading_mnemonic: The readings for the kanji in this word are the kun'yomi readings. Since you've already seen the word 青, hopefully you can just combine it with 葉 (you learned the reading for this part with the kanji). Be sure to pay attention to the rendaku, though. は goes to ば in this word, making it <reading>あおば</reading>.

examples.en: This cushion is very light.
examples.ja: このクッション、すごく軽いですね。

examples.en: I eat light snacks such as fruits and cereal every day for breakfast
examples.ja: 毎日の朝ごはんは、フルーツやシリアルといった軽い物を食べています。

examples.en: With some light exercise, my stress has disappeared.
examples.ja: 軽いエクササイズで、ストレスがなくなりました。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>lightweight</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>lightweight</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading you learned with the kanji is the reading you'll be using here. Because of that, this word is kind of a <vocabulary>lightweight</vocabulary>.

examples.en: I saw a bird carrying a part of the tree.
examples.ja: 鳥が木の一部を運ぶのを見ました。

examples.en: I brought tea to the customer's room.
examples.ja: お茶を、お客さんの部屋に運びました。

examples.en: What? Did you carry all three suitcases by yourself?
examples.ja: えっ、一人で三つのスーツケースを運んだんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>carry</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to carry</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Imagine you have <vocabulary>to carry</vocabulary> a <reading>har</reading>d<reading>co</reading>re (はこ) music fan home after a concert. They spent all night moshing to hardcore sounds, and now they’re too tired to walk. But you? You’re a hardcore friend, so you’re happy to carry them.

examples.en: It's lucky to win a lottery.
examples.ja: 宝くじが当たるなんて、運がいいよ。

examples.en: You're lucky to win 100,000 yen from slots.
examples.ja: スロットで十万円勝つなんて、お前は運がいいよ。

examples.en: We were lucky as there were no deaths or injuries from this typhoon.
examples.ja: 今回の台風では、死人もケガ人も出ず、本当に運がよかった。

meaning_mnemonic: The いい portion means "good." So, when what you <kanji>carry</kanji> is good you are <vocabulary>lucky</vocabulary>. Just think of it in terms of luck being a physical item you carry in your hands. Now imagine yourself carrying it. Now think to yourself "what I'm carrying is good, it's lucky!"
reading_mnemonic: The reading for the kanji in this vocab is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this.

examples.en: When I opened the door, the wind came in from outside.
examples.ja: ドアを開けると、外から風が入ってきた。

examples.en: "Hey. Can you open this wine?" "Of course. It's a piece of cake."
examples.ja: 「ねぇ。このワイン、開けてもらえないかな？」「もちろん。そんなの楽勝さ。」

examples.en: It is a big role to open a fish shop every single morning without missing a day.
examples.ja: 一日も休まずに、毎朝魚屋開けるというのは大役です。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>open</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to open something</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You go <vocabulary>to open</vocabulary> the door. When you do, a huge scream comes out: "<reading>AAAHHH</reading>!" (あ). Imagine giant あ characters flying out of the door you opened as well.

examples.en: The new drama will be released in March of this year.
examples.ja: 新しいドラマの公開は今年の三月です。

examples.en: It's been almost twenty years since this work was released.
examples.ja: この作品が公開してから、間もなく二十年です。

examples.en: The celebrity's private phone number has been released.
examples.ja: 有名人のプライベートの電話番号が公開されてしまった。

meaning_mnemonic: When something is <kanji>public</kanji> <kanji>open</kanji> it is <vocabulary>open to the public</vocabulary>. You can go look at things that are 公開. You can also use this when you're <vocabulary>releasing</vocabulary> something to the public, which means you’re making it publicly accessible.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I am the company president, but I've just started the company and I have no money.
examples.ja: 私は社長ですが、開業したばかりで、お金がありません。

examples.en: My brother is going to start a marketing company next month.
examples.ja: 私の兄は来月、マーケティングの会社を開業する予定です。

examples.en: The business that my friend started abroad has been greatly successful, and this time they're going to do the same in Japan.
examples.ja: 友人が海外で開業したビジネスが大成功し、今回は日本でも同じような事をするつもりだそうです。

meaning_mnemonic:
This is one of those words that has kanji that basically tell you the meaning. You <kanji>open</kanji> a <kanji>business</kanji>... aka <vocabulary>opening a business</vocabulary>.

While this can be used for opening any sort of business, it’s commonly associated with doctors, lawyers, and other professionals opening their own practice or office.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This town is currently under development.
examples.ja: この町は今、開発中です。

examples.en: The leader of the development team is such a big role.
examples.ja: 開発チームのリーダーなんて、大役じゃないか。

examples.en: This company is fully focused on the development of new products.
examples.ja: この会社は新しいプロダクトの開発に全力で集中しています。

meaning_mnemonic: You are now <kanji>open</kanji> for <kanji>departure</kanji>. You get on your boat and leave this place. You are going to another place to start its <vocabulary>development</vocabulary>, where you will create a new world.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I like collecting old marbles.
examples.ja: 私は古いビー玉を集めるのが、すきです。

examples.en: We collected beautiful flowers from all over the country and made handmade bouquets.
examples.ja: 全国から美しい花を集めて、手作りのブーケを作りました。

examples.en: We are collecting feedback from users.
examples.ja: ユーザーからのフィードバックを集めています。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>collect</kanji> and this verb is transitive, meaning the action is done to something or someone. So this verb means things like <vocabulary>to collect something</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to gather something</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You have one of something, but that's not much of a collection. What should you get if you want <vocabulary>to collect something</vocabulary>? <reading>Ah, two</reading> (あつ)! Two of that thing! Yes, when you have enough to say "Ah, two…" you know you've really begun to collect something. Ah, two Crabigator trading cards! See?

examples.en: Let's concentrate during the exam.
examples.ja: 試験の間は、集中しましょう。

examples.en: You should not talk to Dad when he is concentrated in a game.
examples.ja: パパがゲームに集中している時は、話しかけない方がいいよ。

examples.en: I was too focused on the meeting that I've just remembered that I haven't had my breakfast yet.
examples.ja: ミーティングに集中しすぎて、朝ごはんをまだ食べてないことを今思い出しました。

examples.en: In Japan, the population is concentrated in large cities such as Tokyo.
examples.ja: 日本は、東京などの大きな町に人口が集中しています。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>collect</kanji> to the <kanji>middle</kanji> of yourself, you are collecting towards your brain. All energy is going towards there, massing up in the middle, giving you extreme <vocabulary>concentration</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>focus</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Today is the day of money collection.
examples.ja: 今日は集金の日です。

examples.en: Hello, I'm calling to notify you for the collection of money.
examples.ja: もしもし、集金のお知らせでお電話しました。

examples.en: When I went to collect money the other day, the client didn't have enough money, so I got two onions instead.
examples.ja: 先日、集金に行ったら、お客さんのお金が足りなかったので、代わりに玉ねぎを二つもらってきました。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>collect</kanji> <kanji>gold</kanji> you are <vocabulary>collecting money</vocabulary> (or doing <vocabulary>money collection</vocabulary>). Of course, back in the day gold was like money, which is why this word works the way it does. Hopefully you don't have to deal with too much 集金 in your daily life. We'll try to keep WaniKani nice and reasonably priced for you.

集金 often refers to collecting bills, dues, or fees in person or through a designated representative. This can be carried out by a business, an organization, or even just a small group of people.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My mother drinks tea every day.
examples.ja: 母は毎日お茶を飲む。

examples.en: My brother drank some whiskey and his face turned red all at once.
examples.ja: 兄は一気にウイスキーを飲んで顔が赤くなった。

examples.en: Can you drink this tap water?
examples.ja: この水道水は飲めますか？

examples.en: What would you like to drink? Gin, vodka, beer, wine, sake, or chuhai? You name it, we’ve got anything that has alcohol in it.
examples.ja: 何をお飲みになりますか？ ジン、ウォッカ、ビール、ワイン、日本酒、それともチューハイ？ 何でも言ってくださいね。お酒なら何でもありますから。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>drink</kanji> so the vocab verb version is <vocabulary>to drink</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Go have a drink in the great Allicrab's name!

examples.en: This is Mr. Nakayama, an industrial designer.
examples.ja: こちらは、工業デザイナーの中山さんです。

examples.en: It's an industrial area near the house, so there are many factories around.
examples.ja: 家の近くは工業エリアなので、多くの工場があります。

examples.en: With the progress of industrial technology, robots have been used as pets in recent years.
examples.ja: 工業テクノロジーの進歩により、近年はロボットがペットとしても活用されています。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>business</kanji> of <kanji>industry</kanji> is... well... <vocabulary>industry</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I like the shape of the "eye" kanji.
examples.ja: 「目」という漢字の形が気に入ってます。

examples.en: This is not the kanji I learned in elementary school.
examples.ja: これは、小学校で学んだ漢字じゃないよ。

examples.en: Most people from China know kanji, so it is a little easier for them to learn Japanese.
examples.ja: 中国出身だと、漢字を知ってる人がほとんどなので、日本語を学ぶのが少し楽です。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>Chinese</kanji> <kanji>letter</kanji>s... you're finally learning the word for them, the thing you've been studying this whole time for so long! This is <vocabulary>kanji</vocabulary>, your new best friend (they came from China, which is why they're Chinese letters).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: American roads are wide.
examples.ja: アメリカの道路は広いですね。

examples.en: I can't drive through this paved road as there's always construction.
examples.ja: ここは、いつも道路の工事をやってて車が通れません。

examples.en: Please be careful not only for vehicles, but also for bicycles and pedestrians on the road.
examples.ja: 道路には車両だけでなく、自転車や歩いてる人もいるので、気を付けて下さいね。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>road</kanji> <kanji>road</kanji> is obviously the best kind of road. It's double road, after all. So, what is this ultimate road? It is a <vocabulary>paved road</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Never go on the railroad tracks, no matter what.
examples.ja: 線路には、何があっても入らないで下さい。

examples.en: There is a train track in front of the house, so the noise from the train is loud.
examples.ja: 家の前に線路があるので、電車の音が大きいです。

examples.en: My older brother always gets on the last car of the train so that he can see the train tracks.
examples.ja: 兄は必ず線路が見えるよう、電車の後ろの車両に乗ります。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>line</kanji> that runs on a <kanji>road</kanji> is a <vocabulary>railroad track</vocabulary>. First you have to get into your mind that the "line" in question is a railway line. Then, what railway line runs on a road and what kind of road is it? It's a <vocabulary>railroad track</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Many cats live in the alley of the downtown area.
examples.ja: 下町の路地には、たくさんのネコが住んでいます。

examples.en: The fish store is in an alley just off of Western Street.
examples.ja: その魚屋は、西通りから少し路地に入った所にあります。

examples.en: Be careful for your safety when you walk in an alley around here at night.
examples.ja: この辺の路地、夜に歩く時は、安全に気を付けてね。

meaning_mnemonic: If you think about it, an <kanji>earth</kanji> <kanji>road</kanji> isn't going to be the main road. It will be the road less traveled. You could call it a <vocabulary>path</vocabulary> (you know, like a dirt path!) or a <vocabulary>dirt road</vocabulary>. Alternatively, another less traveled street that would probably be made out of dirt back in the day (before everything was paved) would be an <vocabulary>alley</vocabulary>. Imagine yourself walking down a dirt alley at night with no shoes. Scary!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You've learned these readings already, so you should be able to read this word too! And remember, that it's the じ reading that you learned with 生地 here.

examples.en: At school, we learned about the lifestyle of long-ago peasants.
examples.ja: 学校で、むかしの農民のくらしを学びました。

examples.en: The farmers always began working before the sun rose.
examples.ja: いつも農民たちは、朝日がのぼる前からはたらき出しました。

examples.en: The farmers swung their hoes every day until the sun went down.
examples.ja: 農民たちは、毎日、日がくれるまでクワをふるいました。

examples.en: The farmers' hands were steeped in the smell of soil.
examples.ja: 農民の手は、土のにおいにそまっていました。

meaning_mnemonic:
In the olden days, the <kanji>peoples</kanji> who worked in the <kanji>farm</kanji> were the <vocabulary>peasants</vocabulary>.

農民 means <vocabulary>farmers</vocabulary>, but usually not in the modern sense of people who do farm work as their day job. Instead, it refers to the <vocabulary>farming class</vocabulary> — people who were born into a life of farming, often in historical contexts.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: In our town, there are many people who are farming rice.
examples.ja: 私たちの町では、米の農業をしてる人々が多いです。

examples.en: Agriculture is hard work, but it is important for people's lives.
examples.ja: 農業はハードワークですが、国民の生活にとって大切です。

examples.en: I came from Ireland to learn about the culture of Japanese agriculture.
examples.ja: アイルランドから、日本の農業の文化を学びに来ました。

examples.en: The agriculture method called Biodynamics is popular now.
examples.ja: 今、バイオダイナミックという農業の方法が人気です。

meaning_mnemonic: What's another way to call the <kanji>farming</kanji> <kanji>business</kanji>? If you encapsulated it into one word (assuming we're talking about plant farming, here), you could call it <vocabulary>agriculture</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I went to college using a subway called "Tokyo Metro."
examples.ja: 私は「東京メトロ」という地下鉄を使って大学へ行っていました。

examples.en: There are subway exits in various places.
examples.ja: 地下鉄の出口は色々な所にあります。

examples.en: There are many different kinds of people on the New York subway.
examples.ja: ニューヨークの地下鉄には本当に色々な人が乗ってますね。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>ground</kanji> <kanji>below</kanji> <kanji>iron</kanji> is iron under the ground. It isn't a deposit of iron, though. It's man-made. And what's made of iron? Trains. In this case, because it's underground, it's a <vocabulary>subway</vocabulary>. Depending on where you live, you might call it <vocabulary>the Underground</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>the Tube</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>the Metro</vocabulary>
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Our president is a strong man who comes to work after a triathlon.
examples.ja: うちの社長はトライアスロンの後に出社するような鉄人です。

examples.en: This famous female professional wrestler is strong like a badass.
examples.ja: この有名女子プロレスラーは鉄人のように強いです。

examples.en: That man is a French chef, who was once also called the "Iron Chef."
examples.ja: あの男の人は、かつては「鉄人シェフ」とよばれたフレンチシェフです。

examples.en: I saw a tough guy playing peak-a-boo with a baby in a grocery store.
examples.ja: スーパーで赤ちゃんに「いないいないばぁ」をしている鉄人を見てしまった。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>man</kanji> made of <kanji>iron</kanji> is a <vocabulary>strong man</vocabulary>... aka a huge <vocabulary>badass</vocabulary>. Have you seen "Iron Chef?" The Japanese translation is 料理の鉄人, which means "Chef Iron Man" aka "Chef Badass," at least in my book.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Check out the <vocabulary>strong man</vocabulary> wearing nothing but <reading>jean</reading>s (じん). He looks like a badass in his jeans, flexing his pecs. Very impressive, but also slightly terrifying.

examples.en: When I grow up, I want to join an electric railway company.
examples.ja: 大人になったら、電鉄会社に入社したいです。

examples.en: Keio Electric Railway's blue train cars are cool.
examples.ja: 京王電鉄の青い車両はカッコイイですよね。

examples.en: The nickname for the Enoshima Electric Railway is "Enoden."
examples.ja: えのしま電鉄のニックネームは「えのでん」です。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>electricity</kanji> <kanji>iron</kanji> sounds scary, but if you think to back in the day and to where iron was used a lot, you probably think of the railway systems... big hunky pieces of iron on the ground to make the railway. So, you can advance this by adding electricity instead of coal, creating an <vocabulary>electric railway</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This is a Japanese song, isn't it?
examples.ja: これって、日本の歌ですよね？

examples.en: Do you know the name of the song that was playing at the shopping mall today?
examples.ja: 今日ショッピングモールでかかってた歌の名前、知ってますか？

examples.en: It's a song I made for you.
examples.ja: 君のために作った歌だよ。

meaning_mnemonic: One of the kanji's meanings is <kanji>song</kanji> and this word means exactly that: a <vocabulary>song</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

Think about a song... but not just any song... think about the <reading>utter</reading> (うた) song, and make it up right now and sing it out loud. What does the utter song sound like? Why do you love utterances so much that you made a song about them?

examples.en: I want to quit the company and become a singer right now.
examples.ja: 会社をやめて、今すぐ歌手になりたい。

examples.en: There was a Japanese pianist and singer at the restaurant.
examples.ja: レストランには日本人のピアニストと歌手がいました。

examples.en: Cindy Lauper is a famous singer from New York.
examples.ja: シンディ・ローパーはニューヨーク出身の有名な歌手です。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how  手 can sometimes mean “doer”? What do you think a <kanji>song</kanji> <kanji>doer</kanji> is? A <vocabulary>singer</vocabulary>, of course
reading_mnemonic: The readings are on'yomi readings. You've learned them both already (you learned 手's on'yomi reading with word 投手), so you should be able to read this like a <vocabulary>singer</vocabulary> sings with a bunch of <reading>cashew</reading>s かしゅ in their mouth. FAST AND LOUD!

examples.en: The teacher of arithmetic is Tanaka-sensei.
examples.ja: 算数の先生は、田中先生です。

examples.en: Do you have all the tools you need for tomorrow's arithmetic class?
examples.ja: 明日の算数のクラスに必要な道具は全部持ったの？

examples.en: If you don't know the answer on the arithmetic test, you can just say one or four and it'll be just fine.
examples.ja: 算数のテストで答えが分からない時は、とりあえず一か四と答えておけば平気です。

meaning_mnemonic: What is it called when you <kanji>calculate</kanji> <kanji>numbers</kanji>? That is the study of <vocabulary>math</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>arithmetic</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I listen to the radio every day.
examples.ja: 私は毎日ラジオを聞く。

examples.en: I'm sorry to ask you this. Do you have some money on you?
examples.ja: こんな事聞いて、すみません。今お金持ってますか？

examples.en: Why the hell can you as an adult not listen to a person, when five-year-old child can listen to their teacher?
examples.ja: 五才の子でも先生の話をよく聞けるのに、大人のあなたが人の話を聞けない理由は一体何なんですか？

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hear</kanji> so the vocab verb version is <vocabulary>to hear</vocabulary>.

This can also mean <vocabulary>to ask</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to listen</vocabulary>, like asking someone a question or listening to what others are saying. It basically covers anything that involves the act of letting something in through the 門 (gates) of your 耳 (ears).
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You need <vocabulary>to hear</vocabulary> something very important, but you can't. In order to hear, you have to take a <reading>key</reading> (き) and unlock the doors covering your ears. Go ahead and imagine yourself doing that, focusing on the key that lets you hear.

examples.en: I want to be a newspaper reporter.
examples.ja: 新聞ジャーナリストになりたい。

examples.en: In recent years, I check news from the newspaper online.
examples.ja: 近年、新聞のニュースはオンラインでチェックします。

examples.en: Famous newspapers nationwide are, for example, the Asahi Shinbun and the Mainichi Shinbun.
examples.ja: 全国で有名な新聞は、「朝日新聞」や「毎日新聞」などがあります。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>new</kanji> <kanji>hear</kanji> is what it sounds like. It's new things that you're hearing about in your ear... at least that's what it was back a long time ago. Now those new things that get to your ear get to you via other mediums. In this case, a <vocabulary>newspaper</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I go to a Japanese classroom once a week.
examples.ja: 週に一回、日本語の教室に通っています。

examples.en: Does this book have a Japanese version?
examples.ja: この本は日本語バージョンもありますか？

examples.en: I am studying Japanese with a book called "GENKI" and an app called "WaniKani."
examples.ja: 「GENKI」という本と、「ワニカニ」というアプリで日本語を学んでいます。

meaning_mnemonic: You know 日本 is "Japan." So, when you add <kanji>language</kanji> onto the end of that you have <vocabulary>Japanese language</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is just the vocab word 日本 (にほん) plus the on'yomi that you learned for 語. Combine them together to get the reading for this word.

examples.en: I went to college to learn French.
examples.ja: フランス語を学ぶために大学に行きました。

examples.en: Your French is great and I thought you were a French person.
examples.ja: フランス語が上手なので、てっきりフランス人かと思ってました。

examples.en: There are not many French books in Japan.
examples.ja: 日本には、フランス語の本はあまりありません。

meaning_mnemonic: I bet you can guess that フランス means "France." So what happens when you add <kanji>language</kanji> to it? You get the "France Language" aka the <vocabulary>French Language</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is just the on'yomi reading for 語 which is the reading you learned with the kanji. This is probably because it gets added onto a lot of other words so it's treated like a jukugo. For example: 日本語 = "Japanese Language." 中国語 = "Chinese Language." スペイン語 = "Spanish Language."

examples.en: I taught my friend Spanish.
examples.ja: 友人にスペイン語を教えてあげました。

examples.en: Apparently, the pronunciation of Spanish is about the same as Japanese pronunciation.
examples.ja: スペイン語の発音は、日本語の発音と大体同じらしいですよ。

examples.en: Garlic in Spanish is "ajo," which is pronounced "aho." "Aho" means "stupid" in Japanese.
examples.ja: ニンニクはスペイン語で「ajo」っていうんだけど、「アホ」って発音されるんだよ。「アホ」は日本語で「stupid」って意味だよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You can probably figure out that スペイン is "Spain" just by reading it. Add the kanji <kanji>language</kanji> on there and you have the <vocabulary>Spanish language</vocabulary> (or just <vocabulary>Spanish</vocabulary>), if you'd like.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for the kanji portion is just the reading you learned with the kanji. Since it's attached to something, it's like a jukugo word.

examples.en: What is the subject of this sentence?
examples.ja: この文の主語は何ですか？

examples.en: I learned how to use subjects in Japanese class last week.
examples.ja: 先週の日本語のクラスで、主語の使い方を学びました。

examples.en: In Japanese, even if you don't say the subject every time, the listener would often get it.
examples.ja: 日本語では、いちいち主語を言わなくても相手に分かってもらえる事が多いんですよね。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>main</kanji> thing you talk about in your <kanji>language</kanji> becomes the <vocabulary>subject</vocabulary> of the sentence.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I have no time to read a book when I'm at home.
examples.ja: 家にいる時は本を読む時間がありません。

examples.en: I don't think I have the ability to read fast.
examples.ja: 私には速く読む力が足りないと思うんです。

examples.en: After joining the company, I read newspapers on the train every morning.
examples.ja: 入社してからは、毎朝電車で新聞を読んでいます。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>read</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to read</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Go read something else, now.

examples.en: Excuse me. Could you tell me how to read your name?
examples.ja: すみません。お名前の読み方を教えてもらってもいいですか？

examples.en: I can speak French, but I don't know how to read French.
examples.ja: フランス語は話せるけど、フランス語の読み方は知らない。

examples.en: Does this kanji have four ways to read?!
examples.ja: この漢字には読み方が四通りもあるんですか？！

meaning_mnemonic: You know that this has something to do with <kanji>read</kanji>ing and you know that 方 means <kanji>way</kanji> or <kanji>method</kanji>. So, when you think of a "way of reading" you can think of a couple other better words, such as <vocabulary>reading</vocabulary> (aka the reading of a word) or <vocabulary>pronunciation</vocabulary>. Anytime you need to know how something sounds, this is what you'll ask for.
reading_mnemonic: This uses the kun'yomi readings from the vocab words 読む and 方. So as long as you're okay with those, you can apply that knowledge over here.

examples.en: We hear the birds chirping outside.
examples.ja: 外から鳥が鳴く声がしますね。

examples.en: The puppy is barking.
examples.ja: 子犬がワンワン鳴いています。

examples.en: The sound of chickens saying "cock-a-doodle-doo" starts the morning of the farm.
examples.ja: ニワトリが「コケコッコー！」と鳴く音が農場の朝を始めます。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>chirp</kanji> but the verb has the broader meaning <vocabulary>to make an animal sound</vocabulary>. Variations of this include <vocabulary>to bark</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to chirp</vocabulary>, but this can be used for any animal sound.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji. So, spend more time chirping and less time memorizing, okay?

examples.en: All of the lines are crooked.
examples.ja: 全ての線が、曲がってます。

examples.en: What does this line on the map represent?
examples.ja: 地図上の、この線は一体何を表しているんですか？

examples.en: Please have the incorrect spots marked with double lines.
examples.ja: 正しくない場所は、二重線でマークしておいて下さい。

examples.en: The Yamanote train line can take you to many places in Tokyo.
examples.ja: 山手線の電車で、東京の色々な場所に回ることができます。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This also works for "train lines" as well. You'll see this attached onto the ends of names describing them.
reading_mnemonic: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same for this vocab word. Enjoy it!

examples.en: The caterpillar was running next to the tree.
examples.ja: 毛虫が木の横を走っていました。

examples.en: There's a fence made of wood standing next to the house.
examples.ja: 家の横に木で出来たフェンスが立っています。

examples.en: Don't just sit by, you help too!
examples.ja: 横でボーっと見てないで、あんたも助けてよ！

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Please note that this word refers to "the side of something." Not "the left side," for example. That would be 左側.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this vocab is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, lucky you!

examples.en: How are you today?
examples.ja: 今日の調子はどうですか？

examples.en: I will help with housework this week because your mother is not in good shape.
examples.ja: お母さんの調子がよくないので、今週は家事を手伝います。

examples.en: To men who only say flattering things, you should just text them back a heart-shaped emoji.
examples.ja: 調子のいいことばっかり言う男には、ハート形の絵文字だけ返しておけばいいのよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Imagine yourself <kanji>investigating</kanji> a <kanji>child</kanji>. You heard this child was having a rough time, so you need to come check on the <vocabulary>condition</vocabulary> of his home and life. You find the condition to be terrible, and you tell the parents you have to take the child away because of these conditions (imagine them being ridiculously bad... perhaps they raise raccoons in their kitchen?).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The teacher emphasized important points.
examples.ja: 先生は、重要なポイントを強調しました。

examples.en: I want to emphasize that safety is the most important thing during construction.
examples.ja: 工事の時は、何よりも安全が重要だという事を強調したい。

examples.en: I said the same thing many times to emphasize my thoughts.
examples.ja: 自分の考えを強調するために、何度も同じことを言いました。

examples.en: I feel like Barbie dolls twenty years ago were still emphasizing body lines.
examples.ja: 二十年前のバービー人形は、まだボディラインを強調するものが多かった気がします。

meaning_mnemonic: If you use a <kanji>strong</kanji> <kanji>tone</kanji> on certain words, then you are putting <vocabulary>emphasis</vocabulary> on whatever it is you're talking about. It's the <vocabulary>stress</vocabulary> you put on things that are important because your tone gets stronger on those words or syllables.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It is my routine to check the weather in Germany, where my younger sister is, every morning.
examples.ja: 毎朝、妹がいるドイツの天気を調べるのが私のルーティンです。

examples.en: If you are not willing to look it up yourself, ask Alexa now.
examples.ja: 自分で調べる気がないなら、早くアレクサに聞いてください。

examples.en: An American genius scientist came to Japan to examine bird dung.
examples.ja: アメリカ人の天才科学者が、鳥のフンを調べるために日本に来ました。

examples.en: Can you research capybaras and see if they are edible?
examples.ja: カピバラが食べられるのかどうか、ちょっと調べてくれない？

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>investigate</kanji> so the vocab verb version means <vocabulary>to investigate</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You are hired <vocabulary>to investigate</vocabulary> someone's wife. It is said that <reading>she love</reading>s (しら) another man... but you need to investigate her to find out if that's true, for her husband of course.

examples.en: Both parents of this puppy are German Shepherds.
examples.ja: この子犬の親は両方ジャーマンシェパードです。

examples.en: I have to get a signature from my parents.
examples.ja: 親にサインをもらわないといけない。

examples.en: If the parents are both swans, the child should also be a swan, right?
examples.ja: 親が白鳥だったら、子も白鳥のはずでしょ？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

Just imagine your parents saying <reading>oh yah</reading> (おや) over and over at you. What did you do at school today? I beat up this kid. "Oh yah?"

examples.en: I've only told this to close friends.
examples.ja: まだ親しい友人にしか話してないの。

examples.en: I ran into a teacher who I was close with in college on the street.
examples.ja: 大学生の時に親しかった先生に、道でバッタリ会ったんです。

examples.en: No matter how close you are, you shouldn't come into the bathroom.
examples.ja: いくら親しいからって、トイレに入ってきちゃダメだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with some kana and an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>intimacy</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>intimate</vocabulary>! Depending on the context, this also means <vocabulary>friendly</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>close</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Those who are most <vocabulary>intimate</vocabulary> with you hang out with you even when you're doing gross things, like sitting on the <reading>sh*tter</reading> (した). Gross, your family is.

examples.en: Thank you for always being kind.
examples.ja: いつも親切にしていただいて、ありがとうございます。

examples.en: A young lady on the street kindly helped me find my lost wallet.
examples.ja: 道にいたお姉さんが、失くした財布を親切に見つけるのを助けてくれた。

examples.en: When I got to their home, Michael's mom always kindly offered me some tea.
examples.ja: 家に行くと、マイケルのママはいつも親切にお茶を出してくれる。

meaning_mnemonic:
When your <kanji>parent</kanji>s <kanji>cut</kanji> you you'd think they are being mean... but they're not. They are bleeding all the bad blood out of you. They are truly being <vocabulary>kind</vocabulary>. 

Just think of how crazy it would be for your parents to cut you... then think about some kind of twist to make it so they are being kind instead.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I opposed my best friend's thoughts.
examples.ja: 親友の考えに反対した。

examples.en: We are more than friends but less than best friends, don't you think?
examples.ja: 私たちって、友人以上、親友以下よね。

examples.en: I met Rachel last summer and soon became best friends with her.
examples.ja: レイチェルとは去年の夏に出会って、すぐに親友になりました。

examples.en: I'm thinking of giving my best friend a llama as a birthday present.
examples.ja: 親友のバースデープレゼントに一頭のラマをあげようと思ってるんです。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>friend</kanji> who is like one of your <kanji>parent</kanji>s is someone who will look out for you. They are like family, in fact! That's why this word means <vocabulary>best friend</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>close friend</vocabulary>. Just imagine someone who watches over you like a parent would. This is the way to describe them.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: You have something like a thread on your head.
examples.ja: 頭に何か糸のような物が付いてますよ。

examples.en: This apartment isn't that tall, so watch your head, please.
examples.ja: このアパートは高さがあまりないので、頭の上に気をつけてください。

examples.en: What kind of person is a "smart person"?
examples.ja: 「頭がいい人」というのは、一体、どういう人の事ですか？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading which you learned with the kanji earlier. No problem!

examples.en: The red face is due to drinking alcohol.
examples.ja: 顔が赤いのは、アルコールのせいです。

examples.en: I can't remember the face of my teacher from elementary school.
examples.ja: 小学校の時の先生の顔が思い出せません。

examples.en: I should probably drop by at the townspeople's next cherry blossom viewing.
examples.ja: 今度の町民たちの花見には、顔を出しておこうかな。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is kun'yomi, since it's a kanji all alone with nothing attached. Luckily, that's also the reading you've already learned, so associate that with this vocab word.

examples.en: You look more relaxed than before.
examples.ja: この前より、顔付きがリラックスしてるね。

examples.en: This bulldog has a girly facial expression.
examples.ja: このブルドッグ、顔付きが女の子っぽいですね。

examples.en: You look like a person with a big heart.
examples.ja: あなたは、心の広そうな人の顔付きをしてますよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The thing that is <kanji>attach</kanji>ed to your <kanji>face</kanji> isn't a big booger or anything like that. It's something that's always there. It's your <vocabulary>expression</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are both kun'yomi, but they're the readings you've already learned when you learned the kanji.

examples.en: Dry eye is an eye disease.
examples.ja: ドライアイは目の病気です。

examples.en: Yesterday, my classmates didn't come to school due to an illness.
examples.ja: 昨日、クラスメイトが病気で学校を休みました。

examples.en: When you are sick, it is important to go to bed early and have a good rest.
examples.ja: 病気の時は、早くベッドに行って、よく休むことが重要です。

meaning_mnemonic: When your <kanji>energy</kanji> is that of <kanji>sick</kanji>ness, you are probably <vocabulary>sick</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There are times when I can't remember various things because of Alzheimer's disease.
examples.ja: アルツハイマー病のせいで、色々な事を思い出せない時があります。

examples.en: It's been three years since I got severe Meniere's disease.
examples.ja: 重いメニエール病になってから、もうすぐ三年です。

examples.en: In order to deal with my depression, I want to stay healthy physically and mentally.
examples.ja: うつ病と上手く生きていくためにも、心体が元気でいたいです。

meaning_mnemonic: As you can probably imagine, when you add the kanji <kanji>sick</kanji> to another word, you're saying what kind of <vocabulary>sickness</vocabulary> it is; you are mentioning what <vocabulary>disease</vocabulary> it is.
reading_mnemonic: Since this is attached to other words, it's treated like jukugo and gets on'yomi treatment. This is the reading you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: Is anyone sick or injured?
examples.ja: 病人や、ケガ人はいますか？

examples.en: I want the patients to feel better soon, but still I don't want them to come near me.
examples.ja: 病人には早くよくなってほしいですが、やっぱり近づかないでほしいです。

examples.en: Mom, don't let a sick person carry such heavy stuff!
examples.ja: お母さん、病人にそんな重い物持たさないでよ！

examples.en: My sister can be kind of like an angel to sick people.
examples.ja: うちの姉は病人に対してだけ天使のように親切にする事ができます。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>person</kanji> who is <kanji>sick</kanji> is a <vocabulary>sick person</vocabulary>. They are also a <vocabulary>patient</vocabulary>, at least we can hope they are, for their sake.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Every <vocabulary>sick person</vocabulary> enjoys playing on their <reading>Nin</reading>tendo (にん). You have the nastiest flu, but you've still got your Nintendo, so everything is fine.

examples.en: Mt. Fuji is the highest mountain in Japan.
examples.ja: ふじ山は日本で最も高い山です。

examples.en: In American football, the team with the highest score is the winner.
examples.ja: アメフトでは、最もスコアが高いチームが勝者となります。

examples.en: What is the most important thing in life? Is it money? Or is it freedom?
examples.ja: 人生で最も大切な物は何ですか？お金ですか？それとも自由ですか？

meaning_mnemonic: This is the adverb version of the kanji, so it has the same meaning, basically. You can say this is <vocabulary>the most</vocabulary> or just <vocabulary>most</vocabulary>. You can also use it as <vocabulary>extremely</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading for this is a reading you didn't learn with the kanji (the kun'yomi reading). To learn it, let's look at a mnemonic. 

Think of <vocabulary>the most</vocabulary> ridiculous <reading>motto</reading> (もっと) you've ever heard. Now imagine a motto that's even more ridiculous. Here are some actual totally real mottos that are the most ridiculous: "What Can Brown Do for You?" "It's Not for Women" "If It Doesn't Get All Over the Place, It Doesn't Belong in Your Face" and of course, "Why Not Enjoy the Go?"

examples.en: Shaved ice is best to eat in summer.
examples.ja: かき氷は夏に食べるのが最高です。

examples.en: Having a beer after work is the best.
examples.ja: 仕事が終わってからのビールは、やっぱり最高だな。

examples.en: This masterpiece has been popular for decades and is known as the best music in J-pop history.
examples.ja: この名曲は何十年も人気があり、J-POPヒストリー上最高の音楽として知られています。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>most</kanji> <kanji>tall</kanji> isn't literally the most tall. When you think of something high above the rest, you think of something that is <vocabulary>the best</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This is the last time I give you money. Got it?
examples.ja: お前に金をやるのは、これが最後だ。分かったか？

examples.en: I'm going to say thank you to the townspeople one last time before leaving.
examples.ja: 出発する前に、最後にもう一回、町民の人々にお礼を言います。

examples.en: The last scene of this drama is famous.
examples.ja: このドラマの最後のシーンは有名です。

examples.en: When was the last time we met?
examples.ja: 私たち、最後に会ったのはいつだっけ？

meaning_mnemonic: The thing that is the <kanji>most</kanji> <kanji>after</kanji> everything else is at the very <vocabulary>end</vocabulary>. It is the <vocabulary>last</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Lately, I don't go to work and work remotely from home.
examples.ja: 最近は出社しないで家でリモートワークをしています。

examples.en: Recently, I am seriously thinking about a way to become independent.
examples.ja: 最近、私は自立の仕方を本気で考えています。

examples.en: I don't have a TV, so I don't know any recent celebrities or popular songs.
examples.ja: テレビを持ってないので、最近の有名人や人気の曲を全く知りません。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>most</kanji> <kanji>nearby</kanji> is something that happened close to now. It happened <vocabulary>recently</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Phonetic kanji often used for the slang "maji" is the letter for "serious."
examples.ja: 「マジ」というスラングによく使われる当て字は「本気」です。

examples.en: This book is a bit confusing because it uses a lot of ateji.
examples.ja: この本は、当て字を多く使用しているため、少し分かりにくいです。

examples.en: Japanese ateji are difficult for foreigners to understand.
examples.ja: 日本語の当て字は、外国人にとって分かりにくいです。

examples.en: Just like 亜米利加 (amerika), there's also a way of ateji where kanji are selected solely for their sounds and the meaning is ignored.
examples.ja: 亜米利加 (アメリカ)のように、発音が同じ漢字を使う当て字の方法もありますよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
当てる means "to guess" or "to hit", and 字 means <kanji>letter</kanji>. So these are guessed letters? Kind of, they're so-called <vocabulary>phonetic kanji</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>ateji</vocabulary>.

This refers to cases where kanji are used solely for their sound, but not their meaning. There are also some cases of ateji where kanji are used only for their meaning and not their sound, but this is less common.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi reading for 当て and the on'yomi reading for 字. You've seen 当てる in the past, so you should be able to read this portion as well. Combine the two together and you have yourself a nice reading.

examples.en: The panda ate one bamboo plant after another.
examples.ja: パンダが次々に竹を食べました。

examples.en: At the last meeting, ideas came up one after another.
examples.ja: 前回のミーティングでは次々にアイディアが出た。

examples.en: People with various hairstyles came to the restaurant in succession.
examples.ja: レストランには色々なヘアスタイルの人が次々に来ました。

meaning_mnemonic:
When things happen in a <kanji>next</kanji>, <kanji>next</kanji> (next, next, next…) way, they happen <vocabulary>one after another</vocabulary>.

Imagine a factory line for item checking. The people there keep shouting "Next! Next!" because items come <vocabulary>in succession</vocabulary> without stopping!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the word 次 (so it's つぎ), but this time you do it twice. No strange rendaku or anything like that either, which makes everyone happier.

examples.en: Should we replace this part with gold?
examples.ja: このパーツ、金に代える？

examples.en: Please substitute cow's milk with almond milk.
examples.ja: 牛のミルクをアーモンドミルクに代えて下さい。

examples.en: The life of this puppy cannot be replaced with money.
examples.ja: この子犬の一生はお金に代えることは出来ません。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know the kanji is <kanji>substitute</kanji>, and you know this is a verb. There are other similar ones, but this one means <vocabulary>to replace something</vocabulary>. In order to remember that this particular word means "to replace something" focus in on the え. You have an egg in your hands that you notice isn't any good (it's black and moldy). So, you replace it with another egg (or substitute it with another egg, or exchange it with another egg, etc).

This verb is transitive, meaning it has a direct object. You replace something, like that egg!
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this one is the same as 代わる which you learned in a previous level. As long as you know that one you should be able to learn this one's reading as well.

examples.en: Many people in this town go see the eye doctor.
examples.ja: 町民の中には、目医者に通っている人も多いです。

examples.en: Doesn't every eye doctor wear glasses?
examples.ja: 目医者の先生って、みんなメガネかけてない？

examples.en: Today, I went to an eye doctor and got contact lens with my new prescription.
examples.ja: 今日は、目医者に行って新しい度のコンタクトレンズを作ってきました。

meaning_mnemonic: Do you remember 医者 (doctor)? What happens when you add <kanji>eye</kanji> on there? You have yourself an <vocabulary>eye doctor</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is just the vocab word 医者 (いしゃ) plus the reading 目 (め), the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: Please turn right and enter the first room.
examples.ja: 右に曲がって一番目の部屋に入ってください。

examples.en: On that morning, my older brother was the first to leave the house.
examples.ja: その朝、一番目に家を出たのは兄でした。

examples.en: The first person who I wanted to inform that I would be admitted to the University of Tokyo was my father, who supported me throughout my entrance exams.
examples.ja: 東京大学に入学できる事を一番目に知らせたかった人は、受験中ずっと支えてくれた父でした。

meaning_mnemonic:
You've seen 一番 (number one), so what in the world is this eye on the end? This eye (目) is used to mark something's position in a sequence. So, add this to "number one" and you have <vocabulary>the first thing</vocabulary> or simply <vocabulary>the first</vocabulary>.
