Just imagine your collection of eyeballs you have at home. (You have a collection of eyeballs, right?) You have them lined up in a display case and you're explaining the first one to your friend. It's not first because it's the best or anything — you love all your eyeballs equally, after all — but it does happen to come first in sequence in your display right now.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this word is just the vocab word 一番 plus the word 目. If you know both of those readings you'll be able to read this one as well.

examples.en: I'm looking forward to the date tomorrow.
examples.ja: 明日のデートが楽しみです。

examples.en: It's still January, but I'm looking forward to summer vacation already.
examples.ja: まだ一月ですが、もう夏休みが楽しみです。

examples.en: Sake and draft beer are something I look forward to on my days off.
examples.ja: 日本酒と生ビールが休日の楽しみです。

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen the word 楽しい, which means "fun." This is obviously very similar looking, though this one means <vocabulary>looking forward to</vocabulary>. Why? Because it has a み on the end, saying "who is going to have fun? It's <reading>me</reading>! That's why I'm looking forward to it!"
reading_mnemonic: The reading is just like 楽しい, so make sure you know that and you'll be able to read this one as well.

examples.en: This curry uses spices made for Japanese people.
examples.ja: このカレーは、日本人向けのスパイスを使ってます。

examples.en: This game is intended for beginners.
examples.ja: このゲームはビギナー向けですよ。

examples.en: This book is a picture book for children who are about three years old.
examples.ja: この本は三才くらいの子ども向けの絵本です。

meaning_mnemonic: You've hopefully seen 向く and 向ける by now. They mean "to face" and "to turn toward." This has a similar idea. When you add 向け to something imagine you're turning it, aiming it at someone. It's aimed at them, meaning it's <vocabulary>made for</vocabulary> them. Turn a book toward someone, now it's <vocabulary>aimed at</vocabulary> them, it's made for them. See the connection?
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the word 向く so work off of that word to be able to read this one.

examples.en: This research institute is famous throughout the country.
examples.ja: ここは、全国でも有名な研究所です。

examples.en: This shampoo was created at a research institute in the United States.
examples.ja: このシャンプーは、アメリカの研究所で、生まれました。

examples.en: On weekdays, I research literature from the Heian era at the laboratory of Japanese language.
examples.ja: 平日は、日本語研究所で平安時代の文学の研究をしています。

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen that 研究 is "research" from previous vocab, and you might remember 所 can mean "facility." So this word means <vocabulary>research institute</vocabulary> or, of course, <vocabulary>research facility</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help if you know the reading of 研究 already.

Also note that 所 is normal in first reading, but gets rendaku'd in the second reading, meaning しょ becomes じょ. Both readings are valid and they don't affect the meaning, so it just comes down to personal preference!

examples.en: There's a shortcut if you turn down this road to the right.
examples.ja: この道を右に曲がった方が、近道ですよ。

examples.en: Not all shortcuts are safe roads.
examples.ja: 全ての近道が、安全な道という事じゃない。

examples.en: If you take a shortcut, you can go to the cherry blossom viewing venue quickly.
examples.ja: 近道をすると、花見の場所にすぐに行けますよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Taking the <kanji>nearby</kanji> <kanji>road</kanji> will get you to your destination more quickly (because it's more close by!). This is a <vocabulary>shortcut</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>short way</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is a bit weird in this one. It uses the kun'yomi reading for both kanji, even though it looks just like it should be all on'yomi reading. It's like you're taking a <vocabulary>shortcut</vocabulary> with your kanji readings and doing the native Japanese readings (kun'yomi) instead of the more intellectual Chinese ones (on'yomi). Luckily, you've hopefully seen both of these kanji as vocab already. You have ちか for 近 (short for 近い) and you have 道 (みち), just like the word "street" you learned before. Combine these together and you have the reading for this word. Perhaps it's like this because you're combining a couple concepts together into one word, at least when it comes to "short + way."

examples.en: I'm sure they'll be fine. It's okay.
examples.ja: きっと助かるよ。平気。

examples.en: When I left the house, there was a taxi right in front of my eyes and I was saved.
examples.ja: 家を出たら、目の前にタクシーがいて、助かった。

examples.en: The teacher told us in advance what kind of answers we will be asked for on this test, which was very helpful.
examples.ja: 今回の試験については、どんな答えを聞かれるか、先生が前もって教えてくれたので、とても助かった。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 助ける means "to help." This word, 助かる, is related, but it's a bit different. It means to be helped or to be saved. It's intransitive, so it doesn't take a direct object. Imagine shouting "I'm saved!" No direct object, right? Verbs ending in okurigana that rhyme with ある tend to be intransitive like this. You can remember this because if something is ある, it's just there, existing, not acting on anything else. That's why verbs that sound like it are often intransitive too!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 助ける, so hopefully you know that word and can apply that knowledge over here.

examples.en: Summer is the season to eat shaved ice and enjoy fireworks.
examples.ja: 夏はかき氷を食べたり花火を楽しむシーズンです。

examples.en: This weekend, I'm planning to enjoy a barbecue with my friends at the river.
examples.ja: 今週末は、友人たちと川でバーベキューを楽しむ予定だ。

examples.en: This trampoline is very popular now. Both adults and children can have fun on it.
examples.ja: このトランポリン、今大人気なんです。大人も子どもも楽しめますよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You've hopefully seen the word 楽しい, which means "fun." This is basically the verb version (ends in an う sound, right?) of that. That means this is <vocabulary>to enjoy something</vocabulary>, or just <vocabulary>to have fun</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the word 楽しい, so be sure to know that word and you'll be able to apply it over here.

examples.en: It's rude to throw pebbles at people!
examples.ja: 人に対して小石を投げ付けるなんて、失礼だろ！

examples.en: My father got angry and threw a balloon at my mother.
examples.ja: 父は、怒って母に風船を投げ付けた。

examples.en: The prince tried to throw an onion at the vampire for the time being.
examples.ja: 王子は、とりあえずドラキュラに玉ねぎを投げ付けてみた。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that you're <kanji>throw</kanji>ing something that is <kanji>attach</kanji>ing to something else. How else can you say that? The best way would be to say <vocabulary>to throw against</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to throw at</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings just come from two vocab words you've hopefully seen already: 投げる and 付ける. So long as you know the readings for those words, the reading for this word should be no problem for you.

examples.en: In Japan, raccoons are said to be creatures that bewitch humans.
examples.ja: 日本では、タヌキは人間を化かす生物だと言われている。

examples.en: This fox is a genius at enchanting people.
examples.ja: このキツネは人を化かす天才だ。

examples.en: "I’m sorry I couldn't make it the other day. I was bewitched by a fox." "No worries. Things like that can’t be helped."
examples.ja: 「先日は来れなくて、すみませんでした。キツネに化かされちまってねえ。」「心配しないでください。それはどうしようもない事ですから。」

meaning_mnemonic:
You've seen the word 化ける (to transform) before, and here's a related word: 化かす. This means <vocabulary>to bewitch</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to trick</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to deceive</vocabulary>.

Why? In Japanese folklore, foxes, spirits and other yokai often transform in order to bewitch, trick, or deceive humans. To 化かす them, in other words.

This verb is transitive, so it needs a direct object — you bewitch, trick, or deceive someone. You know this because when a fox wants to bewitch someone, they have to <reading>cuss</reading> (かす). They say a magic cuss word that lets them change forms and fool people. Those tricksy foxes…
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 化ける, so make sure you know that word and you'll be able to learn this word's reading as well.

examples.en: No matter how many times you tell me the same story, I still don't understand.
examples.ja: 同じ話を何回されても、よく分かりません。

examples.en: A talk about Japanese toilets again?
examples.ja: また日本のトイレの話ですか？

examples.en: Could you listen to me for just a little bit?
examples.ja: 少しだけでいいので、話を聞いてもらえないですか？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji version of 話 means <kanji>talk</kanji>. This word also means <vocabulary>talk</vocabulary>, but it means a few other things as well. This can refer to a <vocabulary>speech</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>story</vocabulary> as well. Basically anything that involves a talking session. So, before you go, I hope you stay awhile and listen to my 話.
reading_mnemonic:
Who tells a great <vocabulary>story</vocabulary>? <reading>Hana, she</reading> (はなし) tells a great story! If you know someone named Hana or Hanna you can use that person to help you to remember this one better too. 

You can also use 話す's reading to help you to remember this one, as well.

examples.en: Once they've decided on a name for Koichi's baby, I'll let you know right away.
examples.ja: コウイチの赤ちゃんの名前が決定したら、すぐにお知らせしますね。

examples.en: The winner of the contest has been decided.
examples.ja: コンテストの勝者を決定しました。

examples.en: ROFL! This TV show is hilarious, man. I’ve decided that this is now my new favorite show.
examples.ja: クソワロタwwwこのテレビ番組クソほどおもしろいじゃねーかよ。俺の一番好きな番組に決定したわ。

meaning_mnemonic: A 決定 is a "decision." So, when you add する to it you're making it a verb, meaning this word means <vocabulary>to decide</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 決定 with する added. Make sure you know 決定 and you'll know this word as well.

examples.en: In this country, there are not many opportunities to meet Japanese people.
examples.ja: この国では、日本人に出会うチャンスがあまりない。

examples.en: I met various people in this town and they were kind to me.
examples.ja: この町では色々な人に出会って、親切にしてもらいました。

examples.en: Where did you meet your husband?
examples.ja: ご主人とは、一体どこで出会ったんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>exit</kanji> your house and you <kanji>meet</kanji> someone. You didn’t mean to meet them, but it happened anyway. That’s why this word means <vocabulary>to meet by chance</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading is that of the word 出る and the word 会う, both of which you've hopefully seen. The 出 portion may be confusing, but you can usually assume that if one part of the word is kun'yomi / vocab reading, the other part is too, which is why 出 uses the vocab reading.

Oh by the way, this word can be written like this too: 出合う. It’s not as common, but you may come across it every now and then, so it’s good to know!

examples.en: Don't worry, it's okay. Everything should work out.
examples.ja: 心配しないで、平気ですよ。全て上手くいくはず。

examples.en: I'm so worried about tomorrow's exam that I can't feel at ease.
examples.ja: 明日の試験が心配で、安心していられません。

examples.en: I'm a little worried because my father doesn't have the energy like he always had.
examples.ja: 父にいつもの元気がないので、少し心配です。

examples.en: I was worried because I could not tell whether the ship was heading east or west.
examples.ja: この船の進行方向が西なのか東なのか分からなくて心配になった。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>distribute</kanji> your <kanji>heart</kanji> around you, it's like your heart is everywhere at once, but not in your body. You feel frantic, you don't know what to do because your heart is out there. This represents the feeling you have when you have <vocabulary>a worry</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>concern</vocabulary>. 心配しないでね！
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Take note that the ぱい in 配 got rendaku'd from はい, as well.

examples.en: The password is being projected on the screen.
examples.ja: スクリーンにパスワードが映っていますよ。

examples.en: Is it true that you look fatter on TV?
examples.ja: テレビに映ると太って見えるって本当ですか？

examples.en: I wonder if it will properly appear on the screen.
examples.ja: ちゃんとスクリーンに映るかな。

examples.en: Didn't Dad appear on TV just now?
examples.ja: 今、テレビにお父さん映らなかった？

examples.en: During the video call, the dog's face unexpectedly appeared and it was heartwarming.
examples.ja: テレビ電話をしていると、犬の顔がひょっこり映ってほっこりした。

examples.en: I can't forget the beautiful moon reflected in the water that we saw together that night.
examples.ja: その夜、君と二人で見た、あの水に映る美しい月が忘れられません。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>reflect</kanji>. The verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to be reflected</vocabulary>. You're not doing the reflecting directly. You can remember this by thinking how rude (る) it is that someone's reflecting your image using a mirror for everyone outside the dressing room to see.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Your reflection is getting reflected onto the mirror. You don't like it, it doesn't look like you. Impostor reflection! You take a hammer and you <reading>打つ</reading> (うつ) it as hard as you can, glass flying everywhere. Then some dubstep starts playing from the broken mirror: <reading>うつ</reading>うつうつうつ. 

You might recall that this reading is the same as <reading>写</reading>る and might wonder if they're related. They are! They both talk about the image of something showing up somewhere else, and use different kanji to distinguish where. In 写る's case, that would typically be in photographs, and for 映る, it's in reflections or projections (which includes the contents of screens, like those of TVs or computers).

examples.en: I sent an email asking for the replacement of the company president.
examples.ja: 社長交代を求めるメールを送りました。

examples.en: My father is always looking for a new business idea.
examples.ja: 父は、いつも新しいビジネスアイディアを求めている。

examples.en: For customers seeking a tool for learning kanji, I recommend this app called WaniKani.
examples.ja: 漢字を学ぶためのツールを求めるお客さんには、このワニカニってアプリをオススメしてるよ。

examples.en: We had twenty calls asking for a refund just today.
examples.ja: 今日だけで返金を求める電話が二十回ありました。

meaning_mnemonic: What's the verb form of <kanji>request</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>to request</vocabulary>. It also is for when you want something (<vocabulary>to want something</vocabulary>), because if you're going <vocabulary>to request something</vocabulary>, you probably want it.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What is it that you want? You want a <reading>moat</reading> (もと) around your home. Your neighbor's cats keep pooping on your lawn, but if you had a moat they wouldn't be able to get to your lawn in the first place, since cats hate water (and alligators). You request a moat!

examples.en: I joined a private railway company in April.
examples.ja: 四月に私鉄の会社に入社しました。

examples.en: The property values around this area of ​​Tokyo are very high because both a private railway and a JR line are running through here.
examples.ja: 東京のこの辺りは、私鉄もJRも通ってて、土地がすごく高いですよ。

examples.en: In Tokyo, there is not only JR's "Suica" card, but another railway's "PASMO" card that you can use on private railways.
examples.ja: 東京には、JRの「Suica」だけではなくて、他の私鉄でも作れる「PASMO」という名前のICカードもありますよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>private</kanji> <kanji>iron</kanji> (remember how 鉄 often has to do with railroad tracks and the like? Same goes here) is a <vocabulary>private railway</vocabulary>. There are a good number of these in Japan.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Our dog has many demands.
examples.ja: うちの犬は要求が多い。

examples.en: Users are demanding cost reductions.
examples.ja: ユーザーは、コストダウンを要求しています。

examples.en: Whether it's a dog or a person, if you give in too readily to their demands, those demands will only escalate.
examples.ja: 犬でも人でも、要求にこたえすぎると、要求がエスカレートしていきます。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>need</kanji> this <kanji>request</kanji> to happen, so you don't just ask nicely, you <vocabulary>demand</vocabulary> it.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I want to enroll in a private college.
examples.ja: 私大に入学したいと思っています。

examples.en: Many kids at private universities have a part-time job too.
examples.ja: 私大の学生もバイトしてる子が多いですよ。

examples.en: It costs money to enroll in a private university.
examples.ja: 私大は入学にお金がかかります。

meaning_mnemonic: You know how 私 can mean <kanji>private</kanji> and how 大 is the first half of 大学? Well, combine those together and you have the shortened version of <vocabulary>private college</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>private university</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 大 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

You went to a specific <vocabulary>private college</vocabulary> just to study <reading>dye</reading>s (だい). You're so into dyes that you decided to go to this extremely expensive <vocabulary>private university</vocabulary> that specializes in dyes. Good for you!

examples.en: What time does the event start?
examples.ja: イベントの開始時間は何時ですか？

examples.en: A new project will start tomorrow.
examples.ja: 明日から新しいプロジェクトが開始します。

examples.en: Did you tell the president that the start time for the meeting will be delayed?
examples.ja: ミーティングの開始がおくれるって、社長にはもう言った？

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>open</kanji> of the <kanji>start</kanji> is the <vocabulary>start</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>beginning</vocabulary>.

Note that 開始 is slightly more formal than 始める.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This dress makes the curve of the body look beautiful.
examples.ja: このドレスは、体の曲線をキレイに見せてくれる。

examples.en: I like furniture with a curved design.
examples.ja: 曲線を使ったデザインの家具が気に入ってます。

examples.en: Fireworks that look like curved lines have brightened the night sky.
examples.ja: 曲線のような花火が夜空を明るくしました。

examples.en: This road has a lot of curves and it is difficult to drive by car.
examples.ja: この道は曲線が多くて車で走るのがむずかしいです。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>bend</kanji> in a <kanji>line</kanji> is merely a <vocabulary>curve</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Koichi thinks he can solve any problem with money.
examples.ja: コウイチはお金で何でも解決できると思っている。

examples.en: It's still too early to think that everything has been solved.
examples.ja: これですべてが解決したと思うのはまだ早いよ。

examples.en: "Just standing there won't solve anything," said Fugu bluntly.
examples.ja: 「ただそこに立っているだけでは、何の解決にもなりませんよ」と、フグはきっぱりと言った。

examples.en: I can't come up with any good solutions.
examples.ja: いい解決方法が思いつかないんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
You sit down to <kanji>solve</kanji> an issue and firmly <kanji>decide</kanji> on your course of action. This process is called <vocabulary>solving</vocabulary>, and it leads to a <vocabulary>solution</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>settlement</vocabulary>.

解決 is about finding a resolution or bringing a matter to a close. It can be used either for small-scale personal problems or for large-scale problems like social and political issues.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I went abroad to learn various languages.
examples.ja: 色々な言語を学ぶために海外へ行きました。

examples.en: A person who can speak many languages ​​is called polyglot.
examples.ja: 多くの言語を話す事が出来る人をポリグロットと言うんですね。

examples.en: I started going to graduate school last year to learn linguistics.
examples.ja: 言語学を学ぶために、去年大学院へ進んだ。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>say</kanji> words in a <kanji>language</kanji>, you are speaking a <vocabulary>language</vocabulary>. Not sure what that language is, but since you're saying it it must be real.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My older brother is a fast crawl swimmer.
examples.ja: うちの兄はクロールで泳ぐのが速い。

examples.en: Isn't this car going too fast?
examples.ja: この車のスピード、さすがに速すぎない？

examples.en: Ohtani is a fast runner, handsome, and he's perfect as a pitcher or a batter.
examples.ja: 大谷君は、足も速いし、顔もイケメンだし、投手としても、バッターとしてもパーフェクトなんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Just like the meaning of the kanji (<kanji>fast</kanji>) this adjective also means <vocabulary>fast</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Remember how 早い means "early"? If you are early to something, it probably means you moved <vocabulary>fast</vocabulary> to get there. These two words share a reading (and have similar meanings, in a way, as well!).

examples.en: Tokyo Disney Resort is located in Chiba Prefecture.
examples.ja: 東京ディズニーリゾートは、千葉県にあります。

examples.en: It takes about forty minutes by train to go from Chiba to Tokyo.
examples.ja: 千葉から東京まで電車で行くと、大体四十分かかります。

examples.en: Peanuts from Chiba are so delicious that it creates conflict at home.
examples.ja: 千葉のピーナッツは、家の中で対立が生まれるほど、おいしいんです。

meaning_mnemonic: There is only one place in Japan that has a <kanji>thousand</kanji> <kanji>leaves</kanji> and that's <vocabulary>Chiba</vocabulary>. Picture all of those leaves swirling around you on your vacation to Chiba. Beautiful.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a place name and it uses the kun'yomi. You haven't learned kun'yomi for 千 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

While you're admiring all of the leaves in <vocabulary>Chiba</vocabulary>, you realize you're craving something. What goes well with watching leaves? Why, <reading>chee</reading>se (ち) of course. Delicious Chiba cheese.

examples.en: I spoke of my real intentions unintentionally.
examples.ja: 思わず本音を口にしてしまいました。

examples.en: This table was so cheap that I had to get it.
examples.ja: このテーブルは安すぎて、思わず買ってしまった。

examples.en: I involuntarily said, "Are you Nicholas Cage?"
examples.ja: 思わず「ニコラス・ケイジさんですか？」と言ってしまった。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a negative form of the verb 思う which is used as an adverb. If you do something without thinking, you do it <vocabulary>unintentionally</vocabulary>. As an adverb, you can put this in front of things to say that you did them <vocabulary>involuntarily</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this is the kun'yomi reading which you learned already, so you should be able to read this word as well.

examples.en: This standing bar has cheap draft beers and delicious drinking snacks.
examples.ja: この立ち飲み屋は、生ビールが安くて、おつまみもおいしいですよ。

examples.en: Drinking while standing works for me as I'll be taking a train an hour later.
examples.ja: 一時間後の電車に乗るので、立ち飲みで平気ですよ。

examples.en: The other day, I met various people while drinking whiskey at a standing bar.
examples.ja: 先日、立ち飲みバーでウイスキーをのんでいたら色々な人と出会いました。

meaning_mnemonic:
立つ means "to stand," and 飲む means "to drink," right? Well, when you do both at the same time, you're <vocabulary>standing and drinking</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>drinking while standing</vocabulary>.

It also refers to casual <vocabulary>standing bar</vocabulary>s where there are no seats — customers stand while having drinks and light snacks.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are from the words 立つ and 飲む put together.

examples.en: I will start working on cleaning now.
examples.ja: これからクリーニングの作業をします。

examples.en: How was your operation underground?
examples.ja: 地下での作業はどうでしたか？

examples.en: When two people work on a task together, it will get done quickly.
examples.ja: 二人で作業をすると早く終わります。

examples.en: Today, I was working on making an operations handbook all day long.
examples.ja: 今日は一日中「作業ハンドブックを作る」という作業をしていました。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you want to <kanji>make</kanji> a <kanji>business</kanji> successful you need to be prepared to do a lot of <vocabulary>work</vocabulary>. Be ready to handle many <vocabulary>task</vocabulary>s and <vocabulary>operation</vocabulary>s!

作業 often focuses on individual, hands-on tasks that are undertaken to accomplish a specific objective.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 作 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

If you want to get <vocabulary>work</vocabulary> done, you'll first need to get yourself a <reading>saw</reading> (さ). That's because you'll need to cut the work into individual bite-sized <vocabulary>tasks</vocabulary>.

examples.en: If you live in an apartment without sunlight, you would be mentally sick.
examples.ja: この日が当たらないアパートに住んでたら、心が病むよ。

examples.en: I feel like I'm getting sick due to the stress of a new company.
examples.ja: 新しい会社のストレスで病みそうです。

examples.en: Everyone can get sick, so let's be kind to others as much as possible.
examples.ja: だれだって病む事はあるんだから、出来るだけ他人に親切にしよう。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>sick</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to get sick</vocabulary>. 

病む means to fall ill in more formal or literary contexts. In casual conversation, especially among younger people, 病む is used to describe someone feeling down, so this can also mean to get depressed.

Note that this word can be transitive and take a direct object, like 心を病む (to be mentally unwell), but can also be used intransitively without a direct object.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

There is only one time you allow yourself <vocabulary>to get sick</vocabulary>, and that's when the <reading>Ya</reading>nkees (や) are playing. You can't miss any games so you just happen <vocabulary>to fall ill</vocabulary> whenever they're playing so you can stay home and watch. That's pretty convenient, isn't it?

examples.en: I wonder how much this car can sell for?
examples.ja: この車、いくらで売れるかな？

examples.en: Twenty million of these trucks sell every month.
examples.ja: このトラックは毎月二千万台売れるんです。

examples.en: If you put a thousand yen bill on an online auction for five hundred yen, do you think it will surely sell?
examples.ja: 千円札を五百円でネットオークションに出したら、必ず売れると思う？

meaning_mnemonic:
You know that the kanji means <kanji>sell</kanji> and the word 売る means "to sell something." 売れる is the intransitive version of this, so this word means for something <vocabulary>to sell</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be sold</vocabulary>.

It can also be used for something <vocabulary>to sell well</vocabulary>, that often results in that thing beginning <vocabulary>to be popular</vocabulary>.

You can remember this because it's <reading>rare</reading> (れる) to see something sell really well to the point where it gets popular!
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already, so you should be able to read it! It's the same reading as 売る where you're trying to sell some <reading>U</reading>ni (う)!

examples.en: After tomorrow, my mother will be hospitalized for three days.
examples.ja: 明日から母が三日間入院します。

examples.en: Every day since I got hospitalized, my breakfast has been some yogurt and an apple.
examples.ja: 入院してから毎日朝ごはんはヨーグルトとリンゴでした。

examples.en: During the hospitalization, I watched TV and called my friends.
examples.ja: 入院中は、テレビを見たり、友人に電話をしたりしてました。

meaning_mnemonic: So you're <kanji>enter</kanji>ing an <kanji>institution</kanji>. But we're not talking about any institution, we're talking specifically about hospitals. So this word means <vocabulary>hospitalization</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This is a bamboo leaf.
examples.ja: これは、竹の葉です。

examples.en: You can use tea leaves not only once, but several times.
examples.ja: お茶の葉っぱは、一回だけでなく、何回か使えますよ。

examples.en: In November, the mountains are beautiful with the colors from the leaves.
examples.ja: 十一月になると、木の葉に色がついて山が美しいです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: I went to the town hall this morning.
examples.ja: 今日の朝、役場に行ってきました。

examples.en: Is there a convenience store near the town office?
examples.ja: 町の役場の近くにコンビニはありますか？

examples.en: See you in front of the public office at 2:00 p.m.
examples.ja: 役場の前で午後二時に会いましょう。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>service</kanji> <kanji>location</kanji> is a place that people go when they're in need of a service. The best place for this is the <vocabulary>town hall</vocabulary>. Everyone goes to this one location to voice their complaints, and in return their needs are serviced by the officials in the town hall.

役場 specifically refers to the administrative office of a town (町) or village (村) rather than a city (市). Depending on the location, it may be also be called a 町役場 or 村役場.
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the on'yomi reading for the first kanji and the kun'yomi reading for the second kanji. You didn't learn the kun'yomi reading for 場 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

At your <vocabulary>town hall</vocabulary>, you say "<reading>baa</reading>" (ば) when you talk to the clerks. You live in a town full of sheep, so you need to speak Sheepanese whenever you run errands at the town hall. "Baa, baa, baa," you say as you submit a big stack of paperwork to the clerk.

examples.en: My father's tone towards my sister was strong.
examples.ja: 姉に対する父の口調は強かった。

examples.en: Could you please use a more severe tone when talking to your brother who is in high school?
examples.ja: 高校生の弟には、もう少しきつい口調で話してもらえませんか？

examples.en: The teacher always talks in the same tone.
examples.ja: 先生は、いつも同じ口調で話します。

meaning_mnemonic: When your <kanji>mouth</kanji> makes <kanji>tone</kanji>s we call it your <vocabulary>tone</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>tone of voice</vocabulary>. They're different kinds of sounds you make with your mouth that make you sound happy, sad, mean, etc.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 口 yet. Remember when you learned the vocabulary word 口? Just take the ち off and you get its other on'yomi reading く. That's easy, right?

examples.en: What do you plan to talk about at the next seminar?
examples.ja: 次のセミナーでは、何について語る予定ですか？

examples.en: This is a book where a famous writer talks about their life.
examples.ja: これは有名作家が、自分の一生を語った本です。

examples.en: A modern artist talked about their experience living abroad.
examples.ja: モダンアート作家が海外生活の体験を語ってくれました。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>language</kanji>, so when you do language you're going <vocabulary>to talk</vocabulary> about something. Maybe you're going <vocabulary>to tell</vocabulary> a story, or the truth.

This verb is transitive, so it generally takes a direct object in Japanese, even though the English translations might not.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Every time you open your mouth <vocabulary>to talk</vocabulary>, a <reading>cata</reading>pult (かた) within you launches something embarrassing from your past. Catapult strikes again, talk ruined again!

examples.en: This kitchen is spacious.
examples.ja: この台所、広いですね。

examples.en: The kitchen at home is an important space for my mother.
examples.ja: 家の台所は母の大切な空間なんです。

examples.en: In my family, my father is the one who cooks most of the time.
examples.ja: うちでは、父が台所に立つ事が多いです。

meaning_mnemonic: What <kanji>place</kanji> in your house has most of the <kanji>machine</kanji>s in it? Your <vocabulary>kitchen</vocabulary>! Just think about it. Refrigerator, freezer, dishwasher, stove, microwave, WOW! That's so many. The kitchen definitely has the most machines.
reading_mnemonic: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 台 and the kun'yomi reading for 所. You've learned them both so as long as you remember the rendaku, you should be able to read this word too!

examples.en: We ate raw corn at a farm in Aomori.
examples.ja: 青森の農場で生のトウモロコシを食べました。

examples.en: My child started working at an organic tomato farm.
examples.ja: うちの子は、オーガニックのトマト農場に入社したんです。

examples.en: The farm staff gets up every day by 4:00 am.
examples.ja: 農場のスタッフは毎日午前四時には起きますよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>place</kanji> you do your <kanji>farming</kanji> is a <vocabulary>farm</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I left graduate school and immediately got a job.
examples.ja: 大学院を出て、すぐに入社しました。

examples.en: My friend is studying literature in grad school.
examples.ja: 私の友人は大学院で文学を学んでいます。

examples.en: Would you please give me advice on whether to go on to graduate school or try and make a living as a leader for part-timers?
examples.ja: 大学院に進むか、バイトリーダーとして生きていくか、助言をいただけませんか？

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 大学 means "college?" Well the <kanji>institution</kanji> you go to after college is <vocabulary>graduate school</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I remembered this morning, "Oh! The exam is today!"
examples.ja: 今朝になってから「あ！テスト今日じゃん！」って思い出したんです。

examples.en: This morning, it was more winter-ish weather than I expected, so I went to work in my coat.
examples.ja: 今朝は思ったより冬らしい天気だったので、コートで会社に行きました。

examples.en: I got up early this morning and made a handmade breakfast with my dad.
examples.ja: 今朝は早く起きて、お父さんと一緒に手作りの朝食を作った。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Now</kanji> <kanji>morning</kanji> is just another way of saying <vocabulary>this morning</vocabulary>. It's the closest morning to right now!
reading_mnemonic:
This reading is an exception. Let's use this mnemonic to remember it:

<vocabulary>This morning</vocabulary> you want a <reading>quesa</reading>dilla (けさ) for breakfast. You can't wait until tomorrow morning, you NEED it this morning! Imagine eating a delicious quesadilla first thing this morning. Mmm!

examples.en: What is the radical of this character?
examples.ja: この字の部首は何ですか？

examples.en: There are many radical names.
examples.ja: 部首の名前はたくさんあります。

examples.en: The radical for the kanji for "cut" is "sword."
examples.ja: 「切」の漢字の部首は「刀」です。

meaning_mnemonic: Picture the <kanji>part</kanji> of your body that makes up your <kanji>neck</kanji>. Are you picturing it? That's a building block that makes up your body. A really important one. If you didn't have that neck, you wouldn't look like a person at all. Sound familiar? It should! Because that part of your neck is a <vocabulary>radical</vocabulary>! Just like part of your neck is a building block of your body, the radical is a building block of kanji. Get it? I sure hope so!
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 首 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When you need a <vocabulary>radical</vocabulary> to make a new kanji, you just press a button and the radical comes tumbling down the radical <reading>chu</reading>te (しゅ). There's definitely no rhyme or reason to radical picking, it's just whatever pops out of the ol' chute.

examples.en: There is a coin laundry in the neighborhood.
examples.ja: 近所にコインランドリーがある。

examples.en: Those girls over there are the neighborhood's elementary school students.
examples.ja: あの女の子たちは、近所の小学生です。

examples.en: I went to get some miso from a friend in the neighborhood.
examples.ja: 近所の友人にミソをもらいに行きました。

examples.en: The neighbor's dog says "Woof!" towards my entrance door.
examples.ja: 近所の犬が、私の戸口に向かって「ワン！」と大きな声で言うんです。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>place</kanji> you live <kanji>near</kanji> is your <vocabulary>neighborhood</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own as long as you remember the rendaku on しょ making it じょ.

examples.en: My brother is good and fast at adding.
examples.ja: 私の兄は、足し算が上手で早いです。

examples.en: The answer to this addition is incorrect.
examples.ja: この足し算の答えは正しくありません。

examples.en: There will be a test for additions in the next math class.
examples.ja: 次回の数学のクラスで足し算のテストがあります。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 足す means "to add?" Add <kanji>calculate</kanji> to that and you'll have <vocabulary>addition</vocabulary>! It's the type of calculation you're doing when you add.
reading_mnemonic: This is the kun'yomi reading for 足 and the on'yomi for 算. And the さん reading is rendaku'd into ざん. This is the same for all the math-ish words (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), so try to remember that, because you'll see it again!

examples.en: Of course I can do subtraction!
examples.ja: もちろん、わたしは引き算ができます！

examples.en: A subtraction, for example, is "subtracting two from six equals four."
examples.ja: 引き算は、たとえば「六から二を引いて、答えが四」ということです。

examples.en: Although it is a elementary school third grade level subtraction problem, I still can't figure out the answer.
examples.ja: 小学校三年生レベルの引き算なのに、答えがどうしても分からない。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 引く means "to pull" and "to withdraw"? Well, if you <kanji>calculate</kanji> by pulling or withdrawing one number out of another, you're doing <vocabulary>subtraction</vocabulary>. Kinda like how your bank balance gets lower every time you subtract (withdraw) money from it, you know?
reading_mnemonic: This is the kun'yomi reading for 引 and the on'yomi for 算. And the さん reading is rendaku'd into ざん. This is the same for all the math-ish words (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), so try to remember that, because you'll see it again!

examples.en: Please take a numbered ticket and wait your turn.
examples.ja: 番号札をとって、お待ちください。

examples.en: Sorry, wasn't there a numbered ticket around here?
examples.ja: すみません、この辺りに番号札はありませんでしたか？

examples.en: I lost the numbered ticket for my suitcase.
examples.ja: スーツケースの番号札を失ってしまった。

examples.en: Let's get a numbered ticket at the shaved ice shop, then go grab some tea while waiting.
examples.ja: かき氷屋さんで番号札をもらって、待っている間にお茶でもしましょう。

meaning_mnemonic: You know 番号 means "number" so add a <kanji>tag</kanji> to it and you have a <vocabulary>numbered tag</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word (番号) with a single-word kanji added. That means you have two on'yomi readings from the jukugo word and the kun'yomi reading from the single kanji (ふだ). Put them all together and you have the reading of this kanji!

examples.en: When people come, the security lights turn on.
examples.ja: 人が来ると、セキュリティのためのライトが点くんです。

examples.en: Finally the candles were lit, and the tabletop got brighter.
examples.ja: やっとキャンドルに火が点いて、テーブルの上は明るくなりました。

examples.en: When I say "Alexa, turn the lights on," all the lights in the house turn on.
examples.ja: 「アレクサ、電気を点けて」と言うと、家の全ての電気が点きます。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji 点 means <kanji>point</kanji>, but this verb actually means <vocabulary>to be lit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be ignited</vocabulary>. Think of it this way, when a flashlight turns on, it points a beam, of light.

You already learned 点ける, which is for when you turn something on. 点く, on the other hand, is an intransitive verb. That means it happens by itself. Like, "Oh look! The lights came on! That's <reading>cool</reading> (く)!"
reading_mnemonic:
You already learned this reading when you learned 点ける but here's a mnemonic just in case:

Every time you count to <reading>two</reading> (つ) a light comes on. How cool that it does it all by itself!!

examples.en: Walking on a mountain path requires physical strength.
examples.ja: 山道を歩くのは体力が必要だ。

examples.en: There are many turns on this mountain road, so always keep your feet on the brake of the car.
examples.ja: この山道は曲がる所がたくさんあるので、常に車のブレーキの上に足をおいて下さいね。

examples.en: There are many weeds and insects on this mountain road, so please don't come with tank tops, shorts, or flip-flops.
examples.ja: 山道には草や虫が多いので、タンクトップ、ハーフパンツ、ビーチサンダルで来ないでくださいね。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>mountain</kanji> <kanji>road</kanji> is a <vocabulary>mountain road</vocabulary>! Or a <vocabulary>mountain trail</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>mountain path</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Both the kanji in this word use the kun'yomi, which you learned when you learned the vocabulary. When it uses this reading, it sounds casual, and is common in conversation. It can also be read using the on'yomi, though, in which case it has a more formal feel to it. That's typical of on'yomi, which tends to add formality to a word!

examples.en: This UFO is now at an altitude of 33,000 feet.
examples.ja: このUFOは、今、高度3万3000フィートのところにいる。

examples.en: Michael used advanced techniques to complete one difficult game after another.
examples.ja: マイケルは、高度なテクニックを使って、むずかしいゲームを次々クリアした。

examples.en: When the altitude gets too high, the engine will suddenly stop.
examples.ja: 高度が一気に上ると、エンジンが止まっちゃうんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Something that is <kanji>tall</kanji> in <kanji>degree</kanji>s can either refer to its <vocabulary>altitude</vocabulary>, or to the fact that it's quite <vocabulary>high-level</vocabulary>. 

Note that this can refer to any altitude, even lower ones. But when used to refer to, for example, skills or a technique, it always talks about a high level or degree.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Please enter your answer here.
examples.ja: こちらに回答を入力してください。

examples.en: Thank you for your response to the survey.
examples.ja: アンケートへのご回答、ありがとうございました。

examples.en: The president has not yet responded about accepting an interview or not.
examples.ja: 社長はインタビューを受ける事について、まだ回答を出していない。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know 回 means "times," but it can also mean "revolve." You <kanji>revolve</kanji> around an <kanji>answer</kanji> until you're ready to give your <vocabulary>answer</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>response</vocabulary> to the question!

回答 refers to responding to a question, inquiry, or request. For example, you use 回答 when answering a questionnaire or letting someone know whether you can attend a party.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn the on'yomi for 答 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Give me your <vocabulary>answer</vocabulary> and I'll take you to <reading>とう</reading>きょう. How does that sound? All I need is your reply, and we'll be in とうきょう before you know it.

examples.en: This book has more than 500 pages.
examples.ja: この本は五百頁以上ある。

examples.en: This manga is fully colored on all pages.
examples.ja: この漫画は全頁フルカラーです。

examples.en: I cannot see the next page of the PDF because of an error.
examples.ja: PDFの次頁がエラーになって見れません。

examples.en: I read through one page each day.
examples.ja: 毎日一頁ずつ読み進めた。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the vocabulary are exactly the same, so they share meanings as well.

This word is often written in katakana as ページ, especially in informal writing and online. But you'll also see the kanji version, especially to refer to the pages of printed texts and in more formal writing.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the reading you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: Oh, wait a moment!
examples.ja: あ、ちょっとまって！

examples.en: I think it's a little different.
examples.ja: ちょっとちがう気がする。

examples.en: I'll think about it a little.
examples.ja: ちょっと考えてみるよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You <reading>chort</reading>le (ちょっと) <vocabulary>a little</vocabulary> at a silly joke. You can’t help chortling <vocabulary>for a moment</vocabulary>. Go ahead, chortle just a little, for just a moment, to help you remember this word.

examples.en: Oh, I can smell cigarette smoke.
examples.ja: あ、タバコのにおいがする。

examples.en: I've been struggling to quit smoking.
examples.ja: タバコが中々やめられないんだ。

examples.en: It's not good to smoke while walking.
examples.ja: 歩きタバコはよくないよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
タバコ is the Japanese version of the Portuguese word "tabaco." You probably won’t be shocked to learn that タバコ means <vocabulary>tobacco</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cigarette</vocabulary> in English!

Watch out for the first syllable, which is タ and not ト. タバコ can also be written in hiragana, and even in kanji, but katakana is the most common by far.

examples.en: The service at that restaurant isn't great, is it?
examples.ja: あのレストランのサービス、ビミョーじゃない？

examples.en: It's on the house.
examples.ja: サービスです。

examples.en: Eh, it's just lip service, isn't it?
examples.ja: えー、ただのリップサービスじゃない？

examples.en: When I bought cream buns, they gave me bread crusts for free.
examples.ja: クリームパン買ったら、パンの耳、サービスしてくれた。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the equivalent of the English word <vocabulary>service</vocabulary>. By extension, it's often used to mean a <vocabulary>freebie</vocabulary>. Though it's generally used as a standard noun, it can also be a verbal noun used with する. In this case, it means <vocabulary>giving a freebie</vocabulary>.

examples.en: However, that was a lie.
examples.ja: しかし、それはウソだった。

examples.en: However, it was raining that day.
examples.ja: しかし、その日は雨だった。

examples.en: However, she was found by the queen.
examples.ja: しかし、女王に見つかってしまった。

meaning_mnemonic:
<reading>She cashe</reading>s (しかし) in on everything. <vocabulary>However</vocabulary>, this time you're going to stop her. No more cashing in.

しかし is used at the beginning of a sentence, just like "however." It's pretty formal, and you'll see it much more in written Japanese than spoken Japanese.

examples.en: I always eat bread in the mornings.
examples.ja: 朝はいつもパンを食べます。

examples.en: Oh, we're out of bread.
examples.ja: あ、食パン切れてる。

examples.en: It says bread crusts are 100 yen.
examples.ja: パンの耳、百円だって。

meaning_mnemonic:
パン is the katakana version of the Portuguese word "pão" and means <vocabulary>bread</vocabulary> in English.

If you know the Portuguese, Spanish, or French word for bread, you shouldn't have trouble remembering this word. If not, here's a mnemonic to help you:

You use a <reading>pan</reading> (パン) to make all your <vocabulary>bread</vocabulary>. It's your special bread pan, and all the bread you make with it is delicious.

examples.en: Thank you, I am very happy to hear that.
examples.ja: ありがとう、とてもうれしいです。

examples.en: This is a very precious teddy bear.
examples.ja: これは、とても大切なテディベアなの。

examples.en: That teacher's lecture is very easy to understand.
examples.ja: あの先生のレクチャーはとても分かりやすい。

meaning_mnemonic:
Look at this <reading>totem, oh</reading> (とても)! It's <vocabulary>very</vocabulary>, very, very, very lucky, as all totems should be. 

This word has a slightly formal feel to it, and you’ll come across it most in writing.

examples.en: My company is in that office building over there.
examples.ja: うちの会社は、あそこのオフィスビルに入ってるんだよ。

examples.en: I'll call you when I get out of the building.
examples.ja: ビルから出たら、電話するよ。

examples.en: The moon was visible in a gap between the tall buildings.
examples.ja: ビルの谷間に月が見えた。

meaning_mnemonic: ビル is the Japanese version of the English word <vocabulary>building</vocabulary>. It usually refers to buildings that are taller than they are wide, most commonly apartment blocks and office buildings.

examples.en: You should learn an apple pie recipe from Grandma.
examples.ja: アップルパイのレシピは、おばあちゃんに教わるといいよ。

examples.en: Did someone already teach you hiragana and katakana?
examples.ja: ひらがなとカタカナは、もう教わりましたか？

examples.en: Not everything you've learned in school is useful in life.
examples.ja: 学校で教わったことが全て人生で役に立つわけじゃない。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji itself means <kanji>teach</kanji>, and this verb means <vocabulary>to learn something from someone</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be taught something</vocabulary>. When you use this verb, you're not learning something by yourself, you're being taught by someone else.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this kun'yomi yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When you want <vocabulary>to learn something from someone</vocabulary>, you say "<reading>Oh</reading>, <reading>so</reading>..." (おそ) and repeat what you've just learned. Saying "oh, so…" helps you make sure you're understanding correctly, and shows you're really paying attention. That's important when you're learning from someone!

examples.en: The boom will be over soon anyway.
examples.ja: どうせすぐブームは去るよ。

examples.en: That manager left the company last year.
examples.ja: そのマネージャーは去年会社を去りました。

examples.en: Finally, the typhoon has gone away, hasn't it.
examples.ja: ようやく台風が去ってくれたね。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>past</kanji>, and this verb means <vocabulary>to leave</vocabulary>. It should be easy to remember because you know what people say — you leave past in the past.
reading_mnemonic: You will want <vocabulary>to leave</vocabulary>, if you see a <reading>saw</reading> (さ) pointing at you. You know saws can be deadly weapons, you should immediately leave when someone is brandishing one at you!

examples.en: Could you tell me about the plans for the day after tomorrow?
examples.ja: 明後日の予定を教えてもらえますか？

examples.en: I'm going to Japan for one month starting the day after tomorrow.
examples.ja: 明後日から一ヶ月日本に行くんです。

examples.en: Would it be possible to finish it by the day after tomorrow?
examples.ja: 明後日までに仕上げることはできますか？

meaning_mnemonic: Things will be <kanji>bright</kanji> <kanji>after</kanji> the next <kanji>day</kanji>. Or you can think of it as adding an 後 in between your 明日. And what comes after tomorrow? It's the <vocabulary>day after tomorrow</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Unfortunately, the reading for this is irregular, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

"What do you want to eat the <vocabulary>day after tomorrow</vocabulary>?" your mom asks you. You answer, "<reading>Ah, satay</reading> (あさって)?" You're not so confident because you never know what you want to eat the day after tomorrow, but you absolutely love satay, the Indonesian skewers. Ah, satay it is!

examples.en: I made just one mistake on the test.
examples.ja: テストで一ヶ所だけミスをしてしまった。

examples.en: Before the presentation, there's one section that I want to take another look at.
examples.ja: プレゼンの前に、もう一度見ておきたいところが一ヶ所あるんだ。

examples.en: There's one place where it should be capitalized, but it's in lowercase.
examples.ja: 一ヶ所、大文字にしなくちゃいけないのに、小文字になってるところがあったよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember the small ヶ acting as a counter? Together with <kanji>one</kanji> and <kanji>place</kanji>, it makes this <vocabulary>one place</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>one spot</vocabulary>.

Just like 〜ヶ月, you'll also run into this being written as 一箇所, 一か所, or 一カ所.
reading_mnemonic: Just like before, the little ヶ is actually read as か. The rest uses the on'yomi you already learned with the kanji. Just watch out 一 here is いっ instead of いち as it makes it easier to pronounce the whole word. Now, read it aloud and try yourself!

examples.en: Please draw a straight line on the paper.
examples.ja: 紙に直線を引いてください。

examples.en: This shape is made of three straight lines.
examples.ja: この図形は三本の直線でできています。

examples.en: When I glanced ahead, there was a straight row of white stones.
examples.ja: ふと前を見ると、白い石が直線上にならんでいました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>straight</kanji> <kanji>line</kanji> is a <vocabulary>straight line</vocabulary>. You know, the shortest distance between two points and all that.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The car was slowly proceeding straight forward.
examples.ja: 車はゆっくり直進していた。

examples.en: When turning right, watch out for vehicles coming straight ahead.
examples.ja: 右に曲がる時は、直進車に気をつけてください。

examples.en: There's a McDonald's 100 meters straight ahead from here.
examples.ja: ここから直進100mのところにマクドナルドがあります。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you make a <kanji>straight</kanji> <kanji>advance</kanji>, you are <vocabulary>going straight ahead</vocabulary>. 

直進 is a slightly formal-sounding word for <vocabulary>direct forward motion</vocabulary>. You'll often hear it in regard to the motion of vehicles, like when your GPS tells you to go straight at a light or an announcement on the train tells you the train will be going straight at the next junction.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
